text: Lekko zmętniona, żółta barwa. Bardzo owocowy i funky aromat. Dużo jabłek, winogron, agrest, minimalna octowość, ładna beczka. Kwaśne, wytrawne, owocowe, lekko ściągające, z nutami winogron i octu balsamicznego. Bardzo przyjemne.

From a liquor store in CT: pours hazy pale with a white head. Aroma is tree, musty grapes, funk, subdued hops. Taste is funky and a bit tart. Woody and quite dry with just a hint of sweetness. Quite nice.

Bottled. Clear golden body, almost no head but tiny bubbles like champagne. Its a great aroma of cork, wood, grapes, wine berries, flowers. The taste is not overly tart, its like a dry champagne. Wonderfully complex, with red wine overtones, deep sweet notes of port, with a lovely touch of raspberry.

Refrigerated 12.7 oz. brown bottle poured into a tulip. Clear golden with very little white head. Aroma is slightly tart oak, medium body, low carbonation, and no lacing. Taste is tart white grape, oak, and white wine. Good, but expected to like this more.

Havent had a Captain Lawrence beer since (I think) 2007, what a pleasant surprise to say the least. Hazy orange/yellow color, moderate head, some lace/retention. Aroma is barnyard action, oak barrel, vanilla, tart, acidic, yeast, grape. Medium bodied, acidic, tart (not overly so - really nice balance of flavors) with of course brett with some barrel sweetness to round it out.

Lactic sour, oaky Woody, dry grape, white wine aroma and flavor. Not too sour, maybe 4 or 5 of 10 sour and virtually all lactic, but with a little earthy funk in the finish. Carbonation dies fast. Really complex and balanced and a solid sour. A notch below the greats I think with the low dying carbonation and the earthy funk in the finish ( but the earthy funk does compliment the dry oaky white wine and balances with the lactic sour, the earthy funk balance may be a benefit for some... And the more I drink the more I like the balance the slight funk provides). Bumping up a notch the more I have. So complex and so good, only negative now is the lack of carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear yellow white white head. Aroma; Funky, peach, hay, green grapes, green apples. Vinegar and barnyard. Flavours; Peach oak, earth, green apples, acidic with a touch touch of citrus and lime.

March 27, 2016. Bottle, vintage 2015, shared by linusb and Jokestereo, thanks!  Light hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and funky with juicy grapes, apple skins, oak, notes of vinegar, touch of gooseberries. Taste is sour and fruity. Finish is soft acidic with white balsamico notes, juicy grapes, oak notes, earthy and a citrusy touch. Medium bodied, soft to average carbonation 
Very good, nice soft acidity.
A: Clear light yellow with a white head that goes away directly. N: Peach, Muscat grapes, funk T: Grapes, peach, funky barnyard O: Nice fruityness and hint of funk. Decent.
Bottle shared at tasting. Light yellow pour. Nice funky tart aroma. Taste follows. This is really well balanced between the tart and funk. Great stuff.
Bottle shared by Matt - thanks! Slightly hazy light yellow pour with minor head. Cheese and mild funk aroma. Juicy taste with funk and cheese. Intricate and easy drinking. Excellent!

375ml bottle, big thanks to phaleslu for sharing. I got the last 3-4oz. 2015 batch. Wow. Awesome smell. Big, funky, mildly cheesy, oaky nose, with a nice amount of grape character. Hazy golden color. Ring of white head. Some bits of lace. Wow, great flavor too. Awesome moderate to bigger sour taste, moderate sweet. Just a very mild spicy bite. Medium-plus body, mild chewiness to it. Lighter, kind of crisp carbonation. Mild dry in the finish. Awesome funky aftertaste. Very nice sour.

375 ml bottle via trade - thanks again, Charlie! 2015 vintage. Pours a hazy gold with almost no head. Aroma of white wine, lemon juice, oak, herbs and spices, dusty grains, plum skins, wildflowers - really sharp and fresh and tart. Flavor of white wine, plums, lemon, wet hay, grass, mild spices, vanilla, wildflowers, apple, funk, and tannins. Medium-bodied, with modest carbonation and a fruity, vinous, funky, tart mouthfeel that starts cleaner and muddles up over time. Really good but I was picky on this one since Ive been excited for it for a long time. The flavor and mouthfeel just dont deliver like they could, especially based on the aroma.

Draught at the Merchant, 2/9/16.Bright flaxen-yellow body shows a light to moderate haze and is topped by a medium-sized white head that slowly fades to cover.Spice and herbs come out in the nose, up front, and are joined by a buttery oak character that is mitigated somewhat by a strong lemon-like citrus element. Hay and wheat-like graininess in the background is pleasing and helps keep things light and beer-like, while the grape character seems only lightly apparent from the nose (more estery and spicy than tremendously wine-like). Brett shows key limes, pineapple and soft guava notes, lending brightness.Buttery oak and rich, developed brett acids contend with a lightly grainy maltiness that adds a crispness in concert with the tart acidity and light grape must qualities. Light sweetness helps balance (a light, honey-like pale malt) and though its quite woody and barrel-influenced, its never astringent/husky. Floral and fruity notes emerge with warming, but I can never quite shake the slight overabundance of buttery oak that does not go well at all with what the bright, tart, lighthearted brett and grape notes are trying to do. Carbonation is moderately tight, though a touch loose at times. Texture ranges from grainy to softly malty with a touch of oak slickness to it as well. Perhaps this seemed more revolutionary 8 years ago? Its certainly a very competent sour, but doesnt strike me as the best of the best.

Draft at Bru Craft during Sour Bowl II. Slightly hazy bright gold pour with just a slight fizzy white head. VERY oaky sour with some nice vinous juiciness. Muscat grapes. Golden plums. Apples. Nectarines. Applesauce. Lemon. Pepper. Oak. A sharp mix of gentle amber fruit, giant tartness and huge tannins. Medium-full bodied. Seems it might not work but somehow does. Quite shocked. Pretty extraordinary!

Sample, 1-ounce, during the Great American Beer Festival, savoured on September 24 2015; eye: golden, hazy, no effervescence, no head, no lacing; nose: acidity, sourness, green apple, fruity; mouth: acidity, sourness, green apple, fruity, semi-dry sour finale with good presence of green apple, full body, quite carbonated, slick texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, 1 once, en fût, durant le Great American Beer Festival, savourée le 24 septembre 2015; il : dorée, voilée, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : acidité, aigreur, pomme verte, fruité; bouche : acidité, aigreur, pomme verte, fruité, finale semi-sèche aigre avec bonne présence de pomme verte, corsée, très carbonatée, texture coulante; en résumé : bien

500ml bottle (batch 5) thanks to Reynolds in a tulip. Pours hazy golden with a small head. Aroma of sourness, some light grapes, light oak, some pale malts, and some light spices. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Average texture. Glad to have tried this.

37,5 cl bottle, batch #3 from 2009 thanks to Baron! Pours a cloudy yellow with a tiny, white head. Aroma has yeast, fuck, white grapes, slight apricot, dust, white, sweet wine, some vanilla and some leather. Taste is grape fruity tartness, very dry and sweet at the same time. Fruity with lots of sweet grapes and a big, oaky vanilla character. Smooth, oily palate despite the tartness, but very low carb. Delicate and complex!

Bottle shared @ the ever awesome dangerous bottleshare #7 . Batch 3. 
Pours slight hazy orange with almost no head. Aroma is very elegant with notes of smooth and complex brett, grape skin, peach, funky barnyard, fruit fresh (from grapes mostly), tropical white wine, oak and some dry woody notes as well. Very delicate aroma. The taste is tart and dry with notes of dry white wine, peachy notes, grapes, oaky notes, barnyard and some dry champagne. The mouthfeel is a little bit oily and the carb is rather low which suits this beer very well. This was really good! Lived up to my expectations! The age came out very nicely!

Shared at Dangerous Bottleshare #7. Pours hazy dark orange with no head. Aromas of peach, green apples, funk, dirt, lemon zest, vanilla, oak, light vinous notes, grapefruit, elderflower. Taste is sparkling, peachy, lemon zest, tart fruits, grapefruits, light grapes, vanilla, oaky dryness, small amount of brett, some spicy notes. Veryyy smooth!
Bottle. Pours a clear gold with no head. The aroma is oak, apple skin, grapes, funk. Thin mouth, tart grape, light funk, lingering dryness as it warms up, very good.

Bottle, thanks to t0rin0! Batch 4. Hazy hay yellow liquid with medium white head. Aroma of lemon, apple skin, light funk, light earth, white pepper and mineral. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of lemon, apples, light funk and light grain. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation. Really good and clean sour.
Smell is light sour with a saison character. Taste is heavy stone fruit skin. It is semi sweet and semi bitter.
@ RBSG 2014. Yellow coloured with a thin white head. Very sour aroma, fruity. Citrus sour flavour. Great sour.

Batch 4. Enjoyed at home with the wife. Pour is clear golden with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Musty, oaky, lemony, green apples, pears, light spice, and vanilla in the aroma. Taste is bbright green apples, light caramel, allspice, ,some lactic sourness, vanilla, green apples, and lemons with a medium sour finish - highly dry and effervescent. Light body with champagne-like carbonation. Refreshingly sour and the carbonation is perfect. Nice stuff.

5/VII/14 - 12.7 Fl. Oz. bottle @ RBBSG III (Gent) - BB: n/a, batch 5 (2014-716) Thanks to ??? for sharing the bottle!
Bit cloudy light orange to beige beer, small fizzy aery head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: some chlorine, dry, weird, bit chemical, sourish, soapy. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty fruity, chlorine, blueberries, sourish, bit lemony, some alcohol. Nice! Aftertaste: very lemony, bit chemical, orange juice, some blueberries, alcohol.

12.7oz bottle shared by Scott. Poured a hazy straw color with no head. Aroma of white grapes, funk, sour lemons, and light barnyard. Taste mimics the nose. Sour/tart lemon, white grapes, and funk. Amazing

Bottle at RBSG 2014. Thx to everyone for sharing todays bottles!
APPEARANCE: clear blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: brett, wood, grapes, sour.
TASTE: sour, brett, wood. Very nice beer!
Bottle @ RBBSG, 2014. Thanks! Clear yellow, white foam. Medium carbonation. Aroma of sour fruit with vinous notes, fruity! Refreshing and well balanced. Bit onedimensional but very good!

375 ml. bottle sampled @ RBBSG III. Thanks to ??Mathieu87 & PriorL (not sure)??! Pours a very murky peach. Nose is very murky, sour, lots of grape skins, puckering, very tart, lots of yeast, brett, old soggy oak. Taste is very sour, puckering, lots of grape skins, very dry with lots of yeast, soggy old wine barrels. Very murky body, touch vinegar in the back. Very nice beer.
Sampled @ RBBSG III. Hazy pale yellow color, virtually no head. Smell and taste sourness, sour fruits, a bit sharp. Medium body, soft carbonation.

ivorywhite head that bursts away. golden yellow colour. aroma is like cava, vanilla, grape, solvent, boozy, cider, appels, cinnamon, nutmeg. taste like aroma. very dry mouthfeel, very carbonated. wait, is this beer or cava? :) nice!bottle, batch #5

375ml bottle via trade from some dumbo. Pours a very light hazed orange color with no head. Aromas of sour grapes and funk. Taste is initially slightly tart, but the aftertaste is mind blowingly sour. Flavors of sour grapes, itchy crotch infections and unwashed high school wrestlers. Very low carbonation and very easy to pound. Very tight. This beer is very deceiving... First sip is mellow and funky but after you swallow it the aftertaste is intense sourness. Very unexpected. Very good. Grapes all around, with the proverbial dasilky1 "ass fingering". Great fucken beer.

Bottled @ The Hague Tasting, small sample. Horseblanket, tart, hint of strawberry. Lactic acid. Quite nice sour ale, but I didnt expect it to be this high on average rating. Nicely balanced, but lacks a bit complexity.

Bottle @ The No Creepy Country Ticks Tasting, courtesy of JulienHuxely. Pours a clear headless golden beer with slight carbonation going on in the glass. Aroma is light sour, bretty, funky and has some fresh oak influences in there as well. Flavor is light sour, woody and fruity. Light red fruits detected as well as some vineous characters. Great drinkability and refreshing, yet not all too impressive.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2014 Bottle at THT March edition. Hazy gold receding white head. Aroma is really nice, good grassy hay notes, lots of oak, light funk and citric notes. Taste is sour, nice dry mouth feel. Super easy drinking.

Bottle shared thanks to Julienhuxley. Pours cloudy golden wth no head. Aroma of tart fruit, grapes, funk, citrus and light vinegar aspects. Flavour is light sweet and moderate to heavy sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is pretty sour, barn, spices, citric notes. Flavour is mild sourness, some milky notes, some spices. Faint barn. Nice.
Poured hazy light golden with a frothy off white head. Aroma of sour citrus. Medium body, flavour of light, sweet, sour grapes.

sample bottle courtesy of and shared with Julienhuxley @ THT.
No head or carbonation. Cloudy blond pour. Sour. Very good for a sour

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 3/1-2014
375 ml bottle from a trade with brokenasil. Pours darker golden with a minimal head that settles fast. Aroma is tart with vinegar, grapes, lemonjuice and lime. Taste is starts of fairly sour with some acidic vinegar and lemon juice. Finishes of fairly fry with heaps of unripe grapes and som earthy funky notes. Pretty solid!

29/3-2015
2009 bottle. Completely flat. Loads of grapes, light funk, peaches, oaky notes. Super tasty! Bumped the score up .2.

38cl, Batch 5, no mention of ABV, exclusive American brew, with Muscat grapes, thx to Secret Santa!, complex sour brew, sour/fruity and slightly woody/vinous, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, very good brew

Pours a deep golden color with a finger of gaseous bubbles that fade quickly. The nose is bright with lemon, vinous muscat grape, musky barrel, vinegar and a touch of floral roundness. The palate follows with some big floral oak roundness that is cut with lemon, grapefruit some honey maltiness and traces of vinegar and barnyard funk.

A - pours clear apple juice with no head. S - aromas of apple juice, white grape juice up front. Hints of honey, lemon juice and floral notes. M - light medium body. Tart and sweet. Nice combo. Dry sticky mouthfeel. Tart end. T - nice apple/white grape juice up front. Oaky musty notes, honey, floral notes roll across the palate. The end is honey an tart lemon juice. O - a nice combo of tart and sweet. 4.0
Bottle @ Halling Odense It pours clear yellow with a very small white head. sour, fruity, muscat nut, grapes, oak, vinegar, wine flavors.. thanks my friend ! :)
Bottle. Cloudy yellow body with a small white head. Tart, vinegar, yeast, citrus, dust, oak. Delicious.

750mL bottle, batch 2, sent from BrewtopiaofPJ (thanks a lot, Mark), pours a musty looking golden orange with a tiny head. Aroma of oak barrels, grape must, wild bretty funk and some vinous notes. Flavour is super dry, with loads of dry grape must, oak barrels, more grape must, some wild yeast notes, and considerable funk. Very complex and super dry. Not very similar to anything else Ive had. Very light-to-flat in the mouthfeel. Excellent.

A: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Little Light, White Head Ring, Minimal Lacing

S: Sour Mash, Bitter Green Grapes

T: Green Grapes, Lemons, Sour Mash

M: Decent Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Mildly Sour

Overall, a really solid grap based sour, totally recommended.
Bottle at RBSG. From notes. Grapes and loads of lemon citrus. Wow, another great beer. I could drink this all day.

Bottle - thanks Knobbyknobby! Pours hazy golden with a small white head that dissipates slowly leaving a ring that laces well. Aroma is funk, lemon, white grape, fruity, Taste is the same, fruity and funky up front with some sweetness, but quickly drying out and leading to a bone dry, champagnelike finish, with some woody notes coming through along with a touch of astringency from the barrel. Medium body, silky smooth mouthfeel. Quite a nice beer.

Bottle at RBSG. Pour is yellow, mostly clear. Lots of lemon and some grapes on the nose. Tart, wine like taste, but less carbonated. Dry, woody. Needed some water it was so dry. Sour, but not overly so. Really enjoyable.
Bottle. Thanks to foppa78 for sharing. Pours a cloudy golden orange color with white head.  White wine, grapes, tart aromas.  Sour, white grape, oak, tangy flavors.

Bottle @ JetsonFest III, courtesy of foppa78. Thanks so much, Matt! Pours a hazy yellow orange appearance with not much head. Sort of has a rubbery/plastic note to the nose along with some tropical fruit, grapes, and oak. Tangy, sort of lightly sweet malty, vanilla, chewy oak, light grape, pear, somewhat sweet, tart flavor. Kind of cool though I didnt particularly care for the aroma.
Golden and hazy pour. It is very lacto-forward medium to low funk, vinous, fruity, nice.

375 ml bottle shared with Yves Panneels. Pours intense straw yellow with a small white head. Citrussy and spice aromas, light body (a tad too much sourness) and citrus peel in the taste. Nice sour, but less comples than e.g. the Rosso e Marrone

Opened batches 2 & 5 next to each other. 5 was far superior, so I'm reviewing that one. B5 was bursting with flavor whereas the b2 was way over-carbed, mildly flavorful, and a touch watery overall.

Golden, hazy pour; rich white grapes and oak spring from the glass. Citric, mildly funky, fruity & oaky with a healthy sour kick. A well-refined American sour that needs to be brewed on a larger scale. So sad this was my last bottle :(

batch 2+5 opened side by side....

both poured a hazy yellow with very little head.

batch 2:  the carb was off the charts.  flavor was very soft, nice sweetness coming through from the grapes  mixed with oak.  

Batch 5:  significantly more sour than batch 2.  less carb, more well rounded and enjoyable.

375ml bottle, batch 5. First half pours a completely clear golden pee with no head at all. Chardonnay, oak, sour, some green apple skins, Paul says amonia/cat pee but not in a bad way (and I have to agree somewhat), lemons. Probably the most tart beer I have ever had but it takes a little bit for it to hit you and then you pucker up but in a good way, full sour body, cant get over how amazing the finish is, the taste on the palate, and how it keeps on going.

Aroma has slight malt, a little sour, but mostly dry wine like sweetness. Appearance is a orange clear that poured with some head which died quickly. The taste is dry and very cider or dessert wine like. Sourness is present, but accompanied by a full sweetness. Very frothy, but also dry.

Dry and slightly sweet aroma. Gold in color and clear appearance. Almost like a dry wine, it has a very strong sour finish. It lingers for a few minutes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (375 ml) batch # 4. Traded by Preismj, thanks Matt! Clear golden/yellow with a small white head, but almost no lacing. Aroma is of grapes (muscat), fruity notes, oak, vinous notes, acetic notes... complex and interesting. Taste is also of grapes, muscat, fruits, oak, slight acetic notes and some sourness. Mouthfeel is winey and slightly dry. Awesome Sour! Very complex and incredibly well balanced. Not too sour/acetic. Refreshing and drinkable. I would drink this all day.

Bottle served in a Half Acre snifter. Batch #5. Big thanks to cosmicevan for the share.

A: Pours a hazy lemon color with a light orange body. A thin white head forms on the pour and recedes quickly to a thin ring. Some splotches of lace are left behind.

S: Fruity with a little acetone. Sour lemons, a little lactic with some white grape sweetness and tartness.

T: Lactic sourness, some cheek puckering dryness. Oaky finish with some lemon grass and white grape.

M: Light bodied. Puckering tartness with a dry, mildly acitic finish. Medium carbonation

O: Very nice beer. Definitely enjoyed the subtleties of this and the mouthfeel was spot on.

Serving type: bottle

Thanks Dak for sending this! Batch #4 enjoyed in a snifter at 55 Degrees F on my GFs birthday.

A - Pours a still orange hue golden with great clarity and no head. 

S - Lemons and wet grass. Some horsey funk and grape skins.

T - Wow. Huge oak presence in this beer followed by a perfect balance of funk and musty ripened grapes. Grape juice finish, middle is tart and it finishes very dry. 

M - No carbonation, light body. Very dry!

O - This is an amazing beer. Its remarkable and such a pleasure to drink.

Bottle acquired for THE fruit sour tasting. The pours slightly hazy gold with no head whatsoever. The nose is musty white grapes, some mild honey countryside funk. The taste is lactic tartness, sugar-steeped grape juice. Clean acetic funky finish. A bit hot. Medium body, nice active mouthfeel. Overall, quite nice.

Bottle (Batch 5) thanks to Jack at THE fruit sour tasting. It pours hazy light orange with a tiny white head. The nose is more sweet than sour:  lemonade, sweet Muscat grape, sweet apricot, tangerine and only the faintest hint of sourness. The taste is upfront pretty tart, lemon, light acidity, sour white grape, apricot, sherbet, wood and grapefruit with a tart finish. Medium body, prickly carbonation and slightly sticky mouth-feel as it warms up. Not a particularly complex sour but still a pretty tasty one.

Light white small head fades to nothing quickly... Aroma is quite tart, light funk, lightly winey... Fairly lively medium body, bone dry... Fairly sour some light white wine notes... Lightly oaky, fairly complex, dryness makes the flavor stick... Funky aroma, not much in the flavor.... Very very good.. Grape/winey flavor add a lot of complexity....

Batch 5...Pours a hazy honey color with a quickly dissiapting thin white head.  Aroma has nice funk to it...tart winey/grape notes...almost a hint boozy.  Flavor follows suit and adds notes of a lemony tartness and nice earthy/oaky notes...very tart...hint of grassy bitterness.  Mouthfeel is light and a bit lively with a very dry funky/oaky/chardonnay finish.  Excellent.

Batch 4.  Golden pour, slightly hazy.  Aroma of green apple, grape, Brett, slightly funky.  Nice tart flavor with mild funkyness.  Tart apples, lemon, musty basement.  Sweet white grape notes balance the tart.  Light carbonation with a medium body.  Amazing american sour!

Batch 2 received in trade from mcallister, thanks for the opportunity.
Pours a crystal clear deep golden color with a huge white head that dissipates like the head on a diet soda. I can smell the funk as soon as I pop the cap on this one. Lemony tartness mixed with a sour grape fruitiness along with a mild bit of sweet candy malts and a solid hit of barnyard funkiness make up the aroma. The flavor is extreme lemony citric tartness. The grape flavor comes through a little along with a hint of sweet candy like malts and barnyard funk, but this one is all about the tart. Medium body with a spirited level of carbonation and a tart tongue piercing mouthfeel. Nice mouth puckering wild ale.

Batch 3 bottle (thanks to daknole). Pours a hazy peach with no head. Aroma of lovely funk and Muscat grapes. Taste of smooth tartness with a dry, vinous finish. Smooth body followed by astringient finish. Great sour.

Bottle shared by mdfb79 at my place last weekend. Thanks Dan!

Batch 4

A: The beer is a golden hue, which comes as no surprise as this is labeled as a golden ale. There is a white, bubbly head that fizzes away almost immediately after pouring. The beer is mostly clear, with only a slight haze.

S: Apples, grapes, funk, wild yeast, oak,wine, tart fruits.

T: A really delicious sour ale. Apples, grapes and pears balance well with notes of oak and a prominent wild yeast component. There is a tannic presence as well, reminiscent of a fine French sauvignon blanc. Well done.

M: Very tart. Nice feel with a fairly low carbonation level. Alcohol hidden pretty well.

D: A delectable treat. I hope I have the pleasure of indulging in this fine beverage again in the near future. It would be worth driving to the release and waiting in line to obtain this.

Bottle (I believe a few years old) finally shared with brendan and andrew, as a late celebration for the CFA. Pours a light orange body with light cloudy haze and white bubbly, fizzy lacing. Aroma is strong acidic tart, wine and oak. Mouthfeel is tart and dry with notes of white grape, sour tart, vinegar, oak, funky funk, and wine. 
Even though the alcohol content isnt anything to write home about, the combination of the dryness, the vinous flavor and the age have resulted in creating a definite sipper of a sour. Intense funk flavors; Id really like to try a fresh bottle of this for comparison.

Bottle courtesy of James. Thx. Pours opaque pineapple juice color with no head. Aroma is sour vapor and palate is sour white grape with not a lot of berry or red/dark fruit to be found. Good delicate sourness but not a lot of complexity on the palate. Still very tasty.

Sample at Jackie Os during Ohio Brew Week, thanks beace. The beer is a slightly hazy yellow-gold color with a medium thin white head that burns away steadily. Stringy lacing. The aroma is tart apples, oak and herbs. Medium body with a vinous character and notes of apricot, apples, oak and a bit of grainy malt. The finish is fruity and leaves a slightly funky aftertaste. Good beer all around.

28th May 2010Hazy light gold beer. No head at all. A little sour wood and  a distinct muscat nose. Crisp light and semi dry palate. Sour enough to induce an involuntary blink but not a pucker! A little lemon acid offset by sublte oak and nice orangey muscat. Finishes chardonnay winey and dry. Nice winey sour.

Craft Brewers Conference 2012 
Golden in color, hazy with a thin head.  Big sour and Belgian yest aroma and flavor.  Oak flavor and sour finish this is a tasty sour ale.

Pours a hazy gold with no head, looks very simalar to wine. Aroma of funk and sour grapes, tastes a lot like wine with great sour notes. Smooth yet dry, very tasty, sour but not over the top, its just right I wish this wasnt limited because I would drink it all the time!!!

Bottle. Courtesy of Blafa. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small fast disappearing white head. Has a fruity sour tart citrus aroma. Fruity sour tart funky flavor. Has a fruity sour tart citrus finish with weak hints of wood.
Bottle shared by Madvike, thanks Matt. Easy drinking doesnt even properly describe it.  Mild tartness I like this a lot.

Bottle.  Clear light yellow pour, no carbonation and an aroma of tart white grapes and a little lemon.  Flavor is light tart white wine, dry woody sour and very clean on the finish.  Next to some other heavy hitters at this tasting, this really stood out.  I may need to track down some more bottles of this.

Bottle. Pours hazy yellow gold color with a tight white foamy head that fades to a film. Aroma is sour lemon and leather with  farmhouse all around. Taste is more tart lemon grape peel and funky farmhouse. Palate is full and acidic with a dry sticky finish. Awesome!

Light yellow with a touch of haze. Nose is tart but not funk. Taste is crisp clean and super tart. Really well done! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle with Pat down the shore. 12.7 oz. This brew comes sealed in a modest, yet elgant label. Once popped, the brew pours a steady hazy, cloudy bright wheat blonde with a tiny white head that evaporates to leave a smooth, reflective surface. Aroma of freshly squeezed, bitter Concord grape juice, lemon zest, oak, and wildly fermented champagne yeast. Notes of vanilla, honey, and odd Sharpie marker. High, sharp, tight body with a cuttingly sour, grapey, vanilla mouthfeel. Finishes with a sour, grapey Hi-Chew flavor. This is an amazing sour.

Pours golden color. Smells of tart fruit, grapes. Huge big sour grapes here! Very tart up front, reminds me of an effervescent Riesling wine. Pretty light body very active carbonation. I have been lucky to have had this a few times and its always enjoyable.

Appearance: Pours a hazy pastel yellow with no head.

Aroma:  Lemon,wood,funk, grandma perfume.

Taste:  Lemon heads, metallic, funk.Finishes with pleasant tartness.

Mouthfeel:  Chalky. Low carbonation.

Overall: Fantastic.

From notes.  Batch 2, 3, 4, and 5 tasted side by side.  Batch 2 seemed much different than the other two and is worth scoring separately.  The overall score is the score of the newer recipe.

Batch 2:
8/4/9/4/17
Batch 3, 4, 5::
7/4/7/4/15

Tangerine peach color, transparent with a bit of haze.  Lighter, more transparent edges.  A small cap fades to a ring fairly quickly.

The aroma is fairly tart, white grape, lemon zest, and peach.  Acidic and some musty funk.

The flavor is quite sour, although not quite as extreme as the batch 2.  Just a touch of sweetness from the malt, then the white grape comes through a bit.  Peach, a bit of tangerine, and then some lemon zest in an escalating sour flavor.

Bottle, again with huge thanks to Scott. The final bottle of the night, before he fell asleep. Pours clear gold, thin white head, very soft lacing. Nose is tart lemon, cider, just a whiff of the grapes, some nice graininess throughout. Flavours of tart acid, lacto, funk, some cheesy apple coming through. Considering how highly this is rated, I was a bit disappointed in this one...

Opened at a local beer tasting. Thanks Darren!
Ive been gradually growing into sours over the last year or so.  If I wasnt fully aboard the sour bandwagon yet, this one did the trick.  If you dont like this beer, you hate sours (note: you may actually hate beer) Its up there with the best and rightfully so.  Tons of tart, funky fruit, grapes, white wine, and yeast come together to create an amazing beer. The citrus and acidity are spot on for me. Theres not much fault that I could find in this beer.  It basically comes down to preference.  I would love to obtain another bottle of this so that I could enjoy a larger sample.

I finally get to try this thanks to Maltajo, thanks Joe. This batch #4 bottle pours clear gold with thin white head. The aroma offers up apples and pears and then it rolls quickly toward tartness, slight vinegar and then a sense of spicy oak. The taste is delivers big tartness and then some vinegar mixing with a modes level of sweet apples and pears. To midway and into the finish the dry tartness ramps up and lingers along with a thin layer of vinegar right into the after taste. Nice crisp fresh brew. Dig it.

Did a batch 2-5 vertical, but will review the batch 2 since I thought it was the best of the 4. Thanks Matt. Light peach/pale yellow in color, slightly hazy, with some soapy head. Smell is apricot, white wine, smarties/sweet tarts, and some mineral. Flavor mirrors the nose, apricot and a lot of white wine, and some bracing acidity. Light mouthfeel, lively carbonation, and some solid acidity. Great beer, Captain Lawrence really knows there way around an American wild.

375 ml bottle courtesy of tkrjukoff. Shared at epic tasting on February 11.  Pours hazy yellow with a white head that leaves some lacing while dissipating. Smell is slightly sweet and slightly sour with apple juice, kiwi, unripe strawberries, melon, wood and distinct farmyard notes. Taste is slightly sour, slightly sweet and tart with lemon juice, hay, grape zest, wood, spices and leather. Mouthfeel is tart, slightly watery but intense. Finish is dry and tart with citrus fruits.

Bottled 12.7 fl oz at the epic sour beer tasting at _angst_ place, on February 11, 2012Brought by tkrjukoff, thanks!Cloudy yellow color, small white head. Vinous, acidic scent. Acidic, sweet, lactic taste. Sour and lactic aftertaste. Thin mouthfeel, very low bitterness.

Bottle 37,5 cl. Pours hazy golden with a small white bubbly head. Aroma is sour, stable, cellar, tart and fruity. Flavor is sour, tart, aceton, fruity, stable, bitter and dry. Finishes sour dry snd fruity.

Bottle at "Alex surölsprovning 2012". Hazy golden, small head. Sourish rubber aroma, vinous, fruity, grapefruit, citrus, oak notes. Fruity sourish flavor, sweetish, woody, a bit dry, sour, grapefruits. Complex and with nice fruity sourish notes.

Bottled. Courtesy of kappldav123. Lemon peel, brett and grapes throughout. Hints of vanilla. Great complexity. Strong sourness. Some dandelion reminiscence in the finish. Fantastic. Huge thanks kappldav123!

Victory celebration beer after the Giants beat the Patriots AGAIN.  The beer is fantastic and still not worth what I did to get it.  Aroma is funky, grapes, vinegar, barnyard.  Taste is very tart with nice subtle grapes and a crisp clean finish.  The beer is very tart but balanced and tastes great.
Very fresh fruity aroma with tons of funk. Tons of fruit in the flava. Liking the wine barrel agin.

Batch 3
My Super Bowl beer, tasted on 2/5/12 from a capped 375mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours hazy golden with a thin, bubbly white head, that recedes fairly quickly to nothing at all.  The nose is tart and sour with a nice hit of funk, very vinous overall.  As a matter of fact, the closest beverage I have ever smelled to this is an Italian "orange wine".  The flavor is sour lemon peel up front, with a lightly sweet grape note, moving to the barnyard funk which is similar to some wild ciders I have tried.  The body is medium with a nice tannic structure, lighter than average carbonation, and a very long sour grape and funky barnyard finish.  As this warms and evolves, a peachy pitted fruit note comes through with a hint of bread malt.  This is an excellent beer!
Light with a hazy yellow color. Deliciously sour with amazing funk and grape flavor. Yum

375ml shared with mattyb83.  Pours a light golden orange with a little haze.  A lot of carbonation on this one in the glass.  Wow! Wonderful aroma just FULL of brett, lemon, grass, hay, funk.  Some sharp acidity on the nose.  Absolutely wonderful.  Light bodied with flavors of grapes, lemon rind, perfectly balanced oak.  Seems more acidic this year than last.  Just KILLER.  The finish still manages to be soft, yet pretty tart, with some funk and lemon zest rounding it out.  The effervescence whisks the flavors off your palate and leaves you with some cool acidic funk.  Very nice.  Thanks Matty!

This beer is awesome. Clear straw pour with no head. Wicked cheesy brett, massive lemon, and vinous Champagne with a definitely and prevalent earthen note. Amazing brett character all around. Medium body with perfect carbonation. Uber dry finish. Awesome stuff.

(375ml bottle courtesy of maltajo and an assist to Fata2683. Batch 3).  Pours a hazy yellow (and orange) with no head an some sedimentation.  Aroma is funky, fruit, grapes.  Taste is sweet and sour and very tasty.  Medium bodied with a dry finish.  This is superbly balanced between the sweet and sour.  Awesome!

Batch 2, big thanks to CaptainCougar!! Clear golden pour with a small head. Cheesy brett and white wine on the nose, with the flavor following suit, bringing beautiful champagne notes, saison-like dough, and brilliantly tart fruitiness. Great vinous notes as well. Superb.
Bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thank you sir!  Very pale yellow, scant white head. Aroma of subtle peach and apricot, citrus. Taste is rising white bread dough soaked in dry white wine. Very nice.
Batch 2.  Clear pale yellow pour.  Mild aroma.  Notes of grape.  Flavor is sweet at first.  Very wine like.  Tannic and bitter at the end.  Lots of oak.  Not bad.

Bottle batch 3.  Aroma has notes of citrus, lemon, sour funk, and oaky chardonay.  Lovely aroma.  Hazy dirty yellow hue with a tiny white head that fully diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and heavy/medium sour.  Palate is medium bodied and watery average.  Overall a very nice sour.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear golden - small white head. Nice wooden, barnyard, grapes, horsey, sharpness, nice acid, oakey, light peppery sharpness. Lovely. Good complexity.
Pours an unclear and orange beer with no head. The aroma is malt, tart, grapefruit and citrus. The flavor follows the nose with additional acidity. The palate is acidic. Overall a good beer.
Bottle shared by destructo at his TOSPH.  Batch 2, 750ml.  Yellow pour.  Grape and wood aromas.  Sour grape, citrus, and wood notes.

Pour from a bottle and in the glass the beer gave a golden orange color with modest white head. Aromas were a bit horsey, funky, and fruity.Initial flavors were of tart, sour lemon, orange, grapefruit along side the sweetness of the Muscat grapes. The grapes add a nice layer of complexity in addition to the sour flavor profile. Finish is very balanced and long standing. Loved this beer very much. Thanks Robert for sharing.

Smaller traded bottle.  Yep, I could taste the Muscat grapes and I think I noticed some wood or vanilla from the barrels. The sourness reminded me of something like mixing concentrates of grapefruit, orange and pineapple juices. Nice sourness, not necessarily tart or overpowering. Really nice and well made.

Thanks to dedollewaitor. Blind tasted. Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma is light acidic, grapefruit and light barnyard. Flavour is heavy grapefruit, light acidic, sour, leather and barnyard.

Small white head on top of a clear golden beer. Aroma of white wine, geuze-like sourness, wet wood and a hint of ginger. Quite a sharp sour edge on the taste; citrus, hint of vinegar-sharpness, white wine. Slightly fizzy champagne-like mouthfeel.

batch 1 thanks for Joe! served from a 750ml bottle. pours a cloudy golden color with a rough looking head that dissipates quickly. smell is tart white grapes, peaches and much clean funk. a light maltiness. taste is bright with tart grapes, apricot peaches and clean funk. mouthfeel is super smooth but could use some carbonation. Such a great experience with this bottle. it was a pleasure.

Batch 4.  375 ml bottle shared by colonelforbin.  Thanks Mike.    Pours a hazy amber with no head and no lacing.  The aroma is a sweet lemon zest, light brett funk, some white wine grapes, and some light hay.  The initial taste is sweet with wine grape, then the brett funkiness comes in with some lemon and a bit of oak with the funkiness clear on the finish.  Only a light sourness and relatively sweet.  Medium body and close to no carbonation.  An enjoyable beer, but a bit sweeter than I would have preferred.  The mouthfeel would have benefited from more carbonation.

Bottle @ Blindtasting, Odense, July 2011. Pours hazy orange with a creamy off white head. Tart nose of grapes and mould. Tart flavor with notes of brett, horseblanket, oak and grapes. Ends very dry. Nice.
Batch 2 courtesy thecheeseman at the Sea Bass tasting! Cloudy golden pour. Slightly sour white grape aroma with a nice almost dry winey acid kick thats quite pleasant. Nice!

Cloudy golden with a tiny white head. Weak aroma of funk, dusty cellar, wood and grass. Sweetish and tart, mostly fruity flavour with lots of pineapple, some wood, dusty cellar, and herbal notes. Subtle, but quite complex.

Bottle poured into snifter. I probably should have saved this for a tasting but I just couldnt help myself. Hazy orange color with very little head and little carbonation. Aroma has serious hints of sour tartness, cherries and funk. Flavor isnt super sour but has a  nice mellow tartness to it. Just an incredible sour!

Pours a fizzy dark yellow color. At first the head is huge and white, but it fades like sodas head. There are still bubbles rising from their stuck position on the bottom of the glass. A very strong sour odor took my breath away. And not the Berlin style as sung for Tom Cruise. Very funky, peppery aroma. Citrusy, fruity and a little bit like vegetables. But not in a bad way. Slight bitter, sour flavor. Quite tangy. Spicy. Sour, again. Slightly sweet. Leaves some sugar in the corner of the mouth. Tart aftertaste. Not as sour in the end, just tart. Nice sample.

Definitely a top notch American sour.  Has a sort of mulled wine characteristic with the spices accompanying that tart white grape element.  A bit warming.  Ive had bottles on a few ranges of the sour spectrum, from minorly tart (the batch 3 we tried yesterday) to the downright sour/acidic (the batch 1 we tried in Boston).  Consistently great, occasionally unbeatable.

Courtesy of Glouglouburp - thanks for the great brew! Batch 2. Poured out a loud, fizzy white cap that champagne like spritz,is long long gone and a faintly hazy light yellow beer. Killer aroma! Mildy yeasty, sourness, green grapes, pears, mild blue cheese, oak, apricots, mushed up apples, lemon meringue? Snort after snort is excellent and highly satisfying. Tart and sour, intensely refreshing and quenching. Apples, funky cheese stuff, oak, lemon, earth, grapes, wonderfulness. The taste goes on and on and on. Great great taste, probably the best sour Ive ever had. Incredibly drinkable and enjoyable, each sip brings more joy and a rekindling of my need for anything for this style. This is truly a wonderful beer. A unique aroma and taste that continues to impress. Dry and tart, light burn on the after taste. Excellence.
Crushed at GABF 10.  Happy to taste and rate this one.  One hell of a sour.  Mouth-watering goodness.  Sour grapes, some oaky flavor, and a bit of earthy funk.

Head gone in secs, hazed orange-ochre beer. Sour grapes, muscat indeed, Japanese sushi ginger. Sweeter than gueuze, but balanced. Some meaty esters as an extra. citric sourish with a strange sweety (fruity) impression. Tart, dry-out effect. Bit soapy, yet refreshing. Messrs Capt. Lawrence, come over some time, and try an Eylenbosch Druivengueuze. Yes, weve had the definition already signed in Belgium. Since 1979, lol.  Many thanks to Ryan & Victor!

Partial vertical made possible by three separate people. I am reviewing batch 2, 3, and 4.

Beers were poured into wine glasses side by side. None of them had a head or lacing. All were light yellow in color.

Batch 2 - very cloudy and hazy. Im not convinced that it was yeast from being disturbed from the bottom of the bottle. The aroma was quite bretty, Brett b I think mostly, quite funky with a hint of acetic tinge. Beer is oddly thin with a good forward lactic acid, no sweetness, mild tartness.

Batch 3 - very clear and highly carbonated. It looked like champagne in the glass. Very bright. This beers aroma was quite sweeter with cherries and oak. Beer was still quite sour, less brett and funky, dominant lactic with a trail of acetic.

Batch 4 - The newest batch just released a few weeks ago. This beer is cloudy again, moderately carbonated. Aroma is strongly sweet, much much sweeter than the other two. Mostly lactic, not much acetic in this one. The aroma is the strongest out of the three, nice. This beer has quite the brett bite to it, good funk, some oakiness I didnt detect in the others.

Serving type: bottle

(Bottle) Pours clear yellow with a fast decreasing head. The aroma is really fruity, acidic and mild bretty with notes of barnyard, apple juice, citrus, canned fruits like pears and peaches alongside fresh passion fruit, melon and strawberries. Undertones of grapes, subtle spices, sulphur, elder-lemonade and wood. Really interesting and surprisingly fruity nose. Low on phenols. The flavor is dry, heavily bitter and almost no bitterness. Citric, fruity, dry crackers, light brett funk, oak wood/woodshop, grapes and mild spices. The mouthfeel tart, light watery with a near medium carbonation. Puke-burn finish with funk and citrus. Light medicinal. Light to medium bodied.  The best US-style sour ale out there IMO.

Vorwiegend säuerlicher, in zweiter Linie auch angenehm fruchtiger Antrunk mit gutem Apfel-Birnengemisch. Aromatisch, die Säuerlichkeit ist hier Aromenträger und steht nur bedingt im Vordergrund. Ebenfalls aromatisch hopfig, was sich mit der Säure hervorragend verträgt. /12/12/13//12
Bottle courtesy of northernbrews. Pours hazy yellow, with a thin white head. Aroma is huge funk/brett. Body is medium/light. Flavor is sharply sour, with notes of citrus. Nice clean brett finish.

Vertical tasting with my friends Greg & Adrienne,  and Dunnie. We drank a bottle of batch 3 & 4 that were stored in my basement. The batch 3 bottle was Gregs. Batch 3: Pours a clear to slightly cloudy light straw color. The CO2 bubbles moved slower than the batch 4 bottle (kind of weird to notice but I always compare side by side). The nose has a white wine quality with fruity vinous ketones. Mango, melon, lime citrus aslo present. First sip was balanced well between tart, slight malt & alcohol. Not too acidic. Frutiness lingers nicely.   
Batch 4: Pours a slightly darker straw color than batch 3. Nose is similar but not as pronounced with ketones. Pineapple pressent with this one. First sip is a more front of the mouth feel with a puckering quality Similar fruity finish. Batch 3 is better.

Reviewed from notes. Thanks to both bmanning and Azurelimits for opening these.

Poured into a tulip. Appearance is light gold with a white head and a bit of lacing. Nose brings grapes, oak, slight spice, and a nice sourness. Taste is sour but not overdone. Balances well with the fruit and oak presence. Good sour feel with a nice body. Perhaps my favorite sour from them.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-04-2010

750ml bottle, Batch 2.  Pours a lightly hazy, bright gold with a cloudy white head.  Nose is awesome, smells like a classic Cantillon, musty, dandelions, white pepper, white grapes, grass, light band aid.  Great aroma.  Flavor is tart, lemon peel, flower pollen, citrus zest, white sour grapes, lacto, pedio.  Medium bodied, zesty, spritzy finish.  Smooth, refreshing, great flavor.  Great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 BATCH 4 375ml bottle shared with MartinT. 
Appearance : Clear yellow with a small head. Short retentino, no lacing.

Aroma : Awesome tropical brett with nice sourness and citrusy tartness. A bit acetic.

Taste : Awesome tropical fruits, citrusy tartness. A bit acetic, carbonation is a bit soft. 

Overall : Wow very nice beer. The acetic notes are not to my taste but its not too much in this case. Awesome brett flavours, great tartness. Not as good as batch 1 which seemed more bretty (tropical fruits) and slightly less acetic but its still a grand beer. Im lowering my rating to reflect this batch more recent batch. Appearance slightly disapointing.
 
BATCH 1 750ml bottle at saturday night hotel tasting. EBF 2011. 
Appearance : Hazy pale yellow.

Aroma : Awesome citrusy and funky with nice tropical fruits. A little bit lactic and tannic. Best nose ever.

Taste : Great tartness with a nice sourness. Light lactic and tannic. Awesome funk with light dust. Awesome tropical fruits. 

Overall : Cant believe that the first Cuvée de Castleton I try is the batch 1. Thanks to Mike for bringing this. Nose is just divine. One of the most sure 10 I gave until now. Tropical fruits with citrusy tartness is just so perfect. Nice light funk with a little bit of lactic acid and tannins. Taste is also amazing. Cant wait to open my batch 4 to see if its close to this one. 10,4,10,4,20 ; 4.8 Date : 110327.

375ml bottle into my De Struise glass. Batch 4...A light honey gold pour, decent carbonation at first but falls quickly with very light lacing...The aroma is pretty nice, Brute lite; acidic but lightly bready, small oak notes, white wine (sauvigon blanc) characteristics (light grass)...The taste is a bit of let down, displays too many of the white wine qualities in taste and feel. The more you drink the more vinous it gets, more oak and light feeling wine pour through. Weird alcohol finish, but pretty flat.

Huge start, sorry finish, not worth trading much to get

Thank you G311 and Dave for this one. It was from the 2010 release, poured clear dark lemon with a light amber orange hue. There was a small white head and nice cloudiness to the sour ale. The smooth tart notes dominate with light grape notes that settle like a white wine. Its like a Chardonnay that is not super dry. I tasted the 2009 batch aged quite a few months and I thought it was sweeter and better.

Bottle. 12.7 oz. Split with and courtesy of Vinny at my shore house. This brew comes sealed in a modest, yet elgant label. Once popped, the brew pours a steady hazy, cloudy bright wheat blonde with a tiny white head that evaporates to leave a smooth, reflective surface. Aroma of freshly squeezed, bitter Concord grape juice, lemon zest, oak, and wildly fermented champagne yeast. Notes of vanilla, honey, and odd Sharpie marker. High, sharp, tight body with a cuttingly sour, grapey, vanilla mouthfeel. Finishs with a sour, grapey Hi-Chew flavor. This is and amazing sour, up there with any of the elite Lost Abbeys.
375 bottle.  golden color with medium/light head.  i get a lot of pineapple.  This is very good clean american sour ale.  very well done.

Bottle traded in person with MaxxDaddy in NY.
It pours hazy golden and lively bubbly with a small white head. 
The aroma is fruity, orange-apricot like with dry dusty tart note off oak, very pleasant!
Flavour is very fruity mainly sour-sweet apricot with a hint of berries and vanilla. It has a early sweet after taste followed by dry slightly sour notes. 
A little too sweet, but very pleasant.

Bottle shared by Anker. Thanks a bunch!! It pours hazy deep golden with a medium but fast diminishing white head. The aroma is acid, barnyard, orange marmelade, berries, light spices, vanilla, apricot and oak. The flavour is apricot, oranges, citrus, vanilla, sweet berries, sweet fruit, grapes, acid and light balsamicco. Quite complex and very drinkable.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured a pale straw color with a bubbly, white head.  Dry, tart but not really puckering per say.  Champagne like with some nice grape/wine-like tones.  Yeast all the way through, a true joy to drink.

From notes:

Batch 2 750ml. Thanks to onix1ager.

Pour a slightly hazy golden yellowish orange color with a thin half finger white head that immediately fades into a thin ring. Not much in the way of lacing. Visible carbonation.

Earthy funk aroma with lots of bretty effervescence, barnyard mustiness, oak and light fruit notes.

Slightly puckering with a nice amount of light tart sourness that isnt overpowering or acidic at all. Earthy and funky with lots of dry brett, earthy oak and a surprisingly prominent light fruit presence. Slightly vinous with hints of light grape, apple and pear. The fruit is very prominent and adds complexity and a sweetness that balances out the sourness/funk. The combination of balance and light funk make this beer very drinkable.

Pours a golden orange color, with considerable notes of Brettanomyces yeast and Muscat grapes complimented by malted barley. Cuvee De Castleton has a buttery Chardonnay like character from being aged in French oak barrels. 

http://www.billysbeerblog.com/2010/12/epic/

375ml batch 3 opened at my new years beer bash. Pours super bright clean yellow with zero head. aroma is bursting with lemons and acidic fruits. nice barn yard funk interwoven through the citrus. Taste follows suite to aroma to a T. Nice puckering sour that isnt to intense but just makes you want more and more. this is just fantastic.

Batch 4. Shared by a local BA on 09.23.2010.

Pours a hazy, but vibrant aureolin. Liquid peaches.

This is a case of how different something can smell depending on your perspective. My tasting partner said peaches, and I got a good bit of that, but for me the dominating aroma was urea, probably from the muscat grapes. Lots of citrus: lemon myrtle, lemon curd, some tangerine from the esters. My guess is that they used Orange Muscat grapes here, but thats just a guess based on the nose. Brett balances this one out. In the mouth, this is almost a fruit salad: peach, lemon, orange. Some floral attributes as well. A lactic tang keeps me coming back for more. Refreshingly tart. 

I cant help but give this top marks.

A spritzy mouthfeel, this may be ever-so-slightly overcarbonated, but it makes it go down easily. We tried seven very good beers this night, and this was my favorite. Glad I have one still in the fridge.

Bottle.  Pour is a clean golden straw color.  Very pretty how clear this color is.  Loads of tart apple, grapes, and slight gueuze like funk.  Tart apple flavor, with a slight bit of lemon acidity but not too much to make your teeth hurt.  Slight citrus flavors also present.  Champagne like quality to the carbonation with dozens of bubbles constantly flowing the the surface of the beer.  Really one of the best wilds Ive had the pleasure of trying.  Complex without an over powering sourness, and perfect carbonation.  Thanks for the bottle tyler!

Batch 4 courtesy Ryan - thank you!  Yellow, honey/orange in the glass with no head and sparse carbonation.  Aroma is sweet grapes, oak, a hint of tart/sour, and dry background funk of a near-gueuze quality.  Wow!  Taste is massive, mouth puckering sour/tart right at the outset, mid-palate cheese rind funk, lemon, a tease of tart bitterness, and wonderful grape/tart reverberations through the finish.  Dry, precise feel in the mouth throughout.  An absolutely outstanding A-grade sour.

Bottle (Batch 3) shared by badnewsbeers. Murky yellow to yellow-orange body, thin off-white ring of carbonation. Nose is a fruit medley- pineapple juice, banana, and white grape, sweet and phenolic with some spice. Better than Boku. Tart body, not overly sour, with pineapple, banana, white grape, and pear, sweet and reminiscent of an Alsace muscat with more sugar. Very nice interplay of sour, sweet, and fruit notes. Excellent beer.
Bottle. No head. Hazy thick yellow body. Mild oranges lemon aroma and flavor with a fair amount of hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Tried Batch 3 and 4 next to each other. This rating is for Batch 3 because I had a much larger pour of that. Hazy gold pour, almost like watered down pineapple juice. Aroma has sweet and tart features of lemon, brown sugar, and banana taffy. Flavor is tart lemon, bitter grapefruit, and earthy oats. Odd oat and cereal flavors linger. I like the oat quality to a degree. Batch 4 was much better in my opinion: more intense flavors that balanced white wine grapes with plenty of funk.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2011 Bright yellow, film for head. Aroma is full of white grape, faint peach, really enticing. Flavor falls flat a little bit, grape and peach are there, but overwhelmed by the acidity, very vinous. Undercarbonated, flat mouthfeel. Have had a few times now, and havent had the good bottle. Really want to try one.

Bottle:   Dirty straw, cloudy, spritzy white head, nearly no lacing.   Wonderful tart nose.   Comes across as a mini Gueuze.   Very tart on the tongue, lasting, dry, but not to the point where I over salivate.   This one is damn tasty.   Has a sweet aspect to it, along with the dryness.   Not over the top, soft, and very drinkable.   Almost too drinkable.   Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full.   Finishes with a very dry and tart wheaty aspect.   Clean, with an underlying sourness that doesnt go over the top.   Oh man, well balanced, tasty, and right to the spot.   Somewhat subtle compared to others, but it comes across as very well balanced.   I wish I had more of this to share with others.

Bottle. Batch 3. Sparkling golden yellow with small white head. Aroma of huge white grape, sparkling soda, sweet and tart citrus, papaya and grass. Excellent. Flavor of tart grape, lemon and lime juice, yeast, and slowly oak in the finish.  Slight must and sour funk in the finish. Nicely done, and one of a kind.

Sampled at GABF 2010.   Golden yellow pour with some thin white head.  Aroma is sour, funky, a bit of wet lemons, wool and horse.  Pretty strong sour flavor.  A lot of lemony citrus and acidic bite. Includes a lot of funk and oak.  Yeasty, but not overpoweringly so.  Slick mouthfeel.  Pretty awesome beer.  Really, a pleasure to drink.

Big thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle, which was drank alongside Barrel Select, Rosso e Marrone and Flaming Fury. Batch No. 4.

The beer pours a clear yellow color with a white head. The aroma is very fruity. I get some oranges and lemons, as well as the expected grapes. I also get some oaked notes that really come through. The flavor is a great mix of grapes with some oak and lemons. The beer is very dry and is lower on the tartness scale than the other CL sours it was sampled alongside. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice beer that I am glad I got to try.

375ml Bottle (Batch #4):  Complex aroma of wood, tart fruit, muscat grapes, oak, light fruit, acetic acid, light Brett, and a hint of citrus.  Poured pale gold in color with a small, fizzy, off-white head that disappeared quickly.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is medium to heavily tart and heavily sweet.  Tastes of muscat grape, slight Brett, fruit, oak, sugar, acetic acid, apricot, white wine, slight yeast, light vanilla, slight barnyard, and a hint of funk.  Medium body.  Tingly, mouth-puckering, then dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Tart fruit, slight funk, muscat grape, slight oak, and slight yeast finish is sweet and dry.

Bottle
Pours clear pale yellow with nearly no head. Aroma of citrus, grapes and oranges. This honestly looks and smells more like a Sanvignon Blanc, which isnt a bad thing by the way. Flavor is much of the same with a nice dry oak wood flavor. Grapes are prominent and forward on this one. God I loved this beer and need more.

Batch 4 thanks to jcwattsrugger. Pours cloudy yellow orange with lots of carbonation. Nose is tart fruit, champagne yeast and oak. Taste is pleasantly tart, not overwhelming with oak, yeast and light spice.
bottle shared at RBSG10 - really nice caramel. peachy friuty tart. acidic citrus, perfectly balanced with a touch of funk.

Bottle from blklab2007.  Thanks Gianni!  Batch 4.  Pours a clear golden color with a quick fading head.  Nothing at all left on top.  An assortment of bright and fruity aromas; citrusy fruity funk, lemon, oak, white grapes, and a hint of cherries.  Acidic tart fruity flavors; citrus, sour lemon, green apple, white grapes.  Its a bit puckery but nothing too crazy.  Light on the barrel funk.  Medium to light bodied, moderately dry oak finish.  This is very good.

A: The pour is a cloudy straw color with a large white head that dies down to a thin white layer relatively quickly.

S: A wonderful bright acidity to the nose with notes of lemon, green apple, and the muscat grapes used in this beer. Quite a vinous quality to the beer which I really enjoy.

T: A moderate funky quality to the beer that is of the wet oak and must. The sourness is primarily lactic without any real acetic notes. The lemon and green apple character accentuates the white muscat grapes wonderfully, which provide a touch of sweetness.

M: The body is on the light end of medium with a lively carbonation and a pleasantly dry finish.

D: One of my all time favorite sour beers and one that I wish I could drink all the time. Just a great beer that I look forward to at every release.

375 ml bottle. Tasted batch 3 and 4 side by side.

375 ml bottle courtesy of many possible people. I opted to go with the Batch 3 over the Batch 2s I have, largely just because I wanted to save the Batch 2s a bit longer and I wanted to continue my bottle series of 375s put out by Captain Lawrence (2 on display, 2 more to open!). Pours a champagnesque golden hue, well hazed with a big white carbonation driven head that dies to next to nothing, laces minimally. Very carbonated, the beer gives off some very pleasant aromas: a nice funkiness greets the palate, with barnyard, a touch of vinegar, acidic citrus and chardonnay hit the nose pretty strong, with fuzzy peach and pineapple pushing even further ahead of them, a touch dry, the oak comes through well, wet wood dancing on the nose and drying the beer out, vey much like champagne. The funkiness lingers more, of hay and soft cheese at this point. , the sweeter Muscat grapes come into play, a big blast of pineapple I feel, but still leave the brew dry, tart, oaky, with a decent funk on the nose. Initial is medium bodied, letting a good carbonation and prickly sourness dance on the palate. A good fruit body throws white grapes, some pear, and citrusy fruits on pretty strong, light peach, wet wood as well, and a dry champagne yeast feel. The fruit and sourness blend well, with any funk playing second fiddle on the backend. Still, a touch of barnyard brett does come into play, a lively carbonation, and tartness really push it further into the fold though. Some cereal grains, a faint vanilla, and the oak come back. This is really a great beer, especially for a champagne drinker like myself. Dry and fruity, yet well carbonated and sour, although not overbearing like many sours or lambics. The funk, while restrained, still makes its presence felt. This beer has great aging potential and leaves me very excited to open a Batch 2 and see how things progressed over more time. Cheers!
