GABF 2009, day 3: Golden hue. Champagne-like carbonation. Refreshing and clean. Nice amount of sourness. Other elements of hay, brett, leather and lemon. Very well made and a pleasure to drink. Definitely one of my favorites at this years GABF.

Bottle via trade thanks to badbeer on BA.  Hazy golden color with a small white head that leaves just a little foam, and good lacing.  Great aroma, tart with funk, honey, lemon, oak, and floral hops.  Flavor is barnyard funk, honey, floral hops, spices, dry white wine, oak, and lemony bretty tartness.  Nice smooth palate, only slightly acidic.  Overall this is a great sour ale.

9/28/09 notes: poured at 2009 GABF, sampled on four different occasions (its that good!).  For me, this along with Raspberry Eisbock were the show-stoppers.  Pours a brilliant cloudy gold with a small head.  Nose is funky, with a lemony acidity.  Palate is buttery smooth, with a touch of effervescence that makes for a heavenly mouthfeel.  Flavor actually begins a bit milder, hitting with bretty funk and sweet lemonade.  The mid-palate is where this beer really crescendos, layering lemon zest, lemon pith, hibiscus, and oak.  Comes off like a blend of mature white wine, fresh lemon juice, brett, and a good dose of age.  I came away muttering wow over and over again under my breath!

GABF 2009:  Dry, vivid fumes of muscat grape essence with nice complimenting acidity lift from the cloudy yellow liquid.  Little to no lasting head.  Flavors are sour yet capture everything good about the muscat grape..EVERYTHING.  its dry, the grape flavors are vivid and inviting...theres almost a subtle yet likable solventy funk in the finish.  Damn fine.
Sampled at GABF 2009.  Pale yellow pour.  Aroma of barnyard funk and sour lemon.  Tart, oak, cherry, and vinegary taste.  An outstanding sour ale.

Batch 3. Pours a hazy golden orange color topped by a small, foamy white head that receds quickly to a thin film. The aroma is a really nice medley of fresh tart grapefruits, grape skins, and lemon. Some tart peaches, wild yeast, and oak round out the nose. Its a very fruity and vinous smell. The flavor follows and strikes a good balance between tart fruits and lactic sweetness. Soured grapefruit, tart peaches, and muscat grapes rush forward on the flavors and the french oak really ties everything together by adding a nice vinous feel to it all. The funk is definitely there, but I could see this getting funkier over time. Medium bodied and smooth mouthfeel with fine carbonation that leads to a dry and very refreshing finish. This one is nice and tart, but not overly so which begs this to be savored. This is an awesome sour ale, one I need to attain more bottles of. I cant wait to try this again and the other sour ales Captain Lawrence is producing.

Sampled at the 09 RBPTE, courtesy of sonicdescent. Heavy funky nose with horse blanket and barnyard, light malt and a bit of floral hops. Sour and funky nose. Light yellow, slightly cloudy body with a diminishing off-white frothy head. Light body, thin, with heavy carbonation and a chalky finish. Heavily acidic and sour, great tartness with only light bitterness. Finish and after is tart and lightly chalky. Nice sour ale.
batch 2 thanks to kan.Hazy straw colored pour. Lavender, clove, bananna on the nose. Tart grape and soft floral spice, nice brett character.

Thanks a bunch to little breeze for sending this treat along 
I have been sitting on this batch two bottle for a while .I cracked it open last Thursday. Review from notes I just found. Bottle split three ways in tulip glasses. It produced a short lasting white head on a cloudy greenish yellow body.
The first thing that hit me was the wonderful Bret character in the aroma along with that comes some lemon and a slight note of sour apple. Nice feel in the mouth department comes off like champagne. The flavor is reminiscent of the nose. A nice tartness reminding me of lemons and sour apples were just some of the flavors I got.
This is an exceptional Wild ale reminded me of Gueuze in a lot of ways. The drinkability is right on for a sour. I will seek this one out again, by far my favorite Captain Lawrence

Shared at Wild the Wild Beers Are 2009.  The aroma is funk, sour lemon, leather, spicy.  the appearance is a hazy yellow, white head.  The flvor is a tart peach, other citrus, sweet.  The finish is like tart fruit candy.  Very enjoyable.
Slightly cloudy golden yellow ale.  Raw yeasty aroma with sourness from the wild addition.

To celebrate my 300th sour rating. Hazy yellow with a white short lasting head. Aroma was somewhat fruity and tart with notes of barnyard, lemons, brett and lacto. Flavour was sour and had brett, lacto, grapefruits, barnyard and wood. Finished sour. Lovely.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 750 ml bottle - batch #2; thanks BVC; pours super cloudy straw gold; thin white head lingers; texture is perfect - soft, fruity with mild zing on the lips; nothing too aggressive here as this is a complex, subtle sour;white grapes, white wine and sweetness from the barrel; a touch of spice and bretty dryness; I really enjoyed this and my top one in this night of sours; a delight to savor and drink

What should have been my 1300 thanks to BMan1113VR. Batch 3 from July. Pours a cloudy translucent color that looks like unpasteurized apple cider. No real head to speak of. Nose: canned pineapple, apple cider, passion fruits, wildflower honey, violets, white pepper and a little bit of yarn (horseblanket maybe?) Taste is pretzels, unnamed citrus fruits, violets, a little bit of wild flavor, sweet and sour sauce (light), and a bit of oak. Mouthfeel is acidic, carbonated, not extremely lively but large bubbles caress your palate like a sparkling wine. very enjoyable.

Batch 3 thanks to dchmela. Pours with a hazy golden body with a small white head that reverts to a ring quickly. Aroma is awesome and complex with honeysuckle, mango, peach, exotic fruits, tang, and passion fruit. Taste is tart, acidic with sour peaches and a slight spicy bitterness that I cant explain (and I think will mellow with time). I get a bit of grape vinousness, tannins, florals and fresh apricot. Acidic mouthfeel with large and sharp bubbles. Would be amazingly awesome in another in another year or two!

Bottle Batch #3 @ WTF OMG! Poured a hazy yellow. Nose is white wine, grapey, some spice, sharp sourness, funky. Flavor is mild blend of wine, vinegar, young fruits and lactic sourness. Mild funk. Young, but great!
Bottle batch 3 Pours out a cloudy yellow topped with a small head. Aroma was of spice, oak, and some berries. Taste light oak, some citrus tart and the berries showing threw. Thanks Sam.

375ml bottle thanks to bret27 (another awesome little bottle for belgian-style homebrew).   Hazy blond color with a somewhat fizzy, yet lasting white head.   The aroma is an intense blast of zesty and sour lemons and other fruit, but also has a nice soft sweetness that rounds it out and keeps your nose returning for more.   The flavor has a relatively simple tart, lemony yoghurt, and apple flavor, with a very acidic finish.   The oak and grapes play second fiddle to the bacteria, but add nice nuance.   Almost creamy in texture with soft carbonation.   This is really sour stuff, but has a soft, balanced feel overall that makes it very drinkable and inviting.

Bottle courtesy bret27. Poured into a 400 mL Bruery tulip. Hazy opaque light-goldenrod color with a filmy white head. Aroma is lemony with light meringue sweetness, some brett, apple, phenols, and a vinous note. Flavor of wine grapes, lemon, sour apple, chlorine, pepper, a hint of woody tannin. Great complexity all around. Not a ton of acidity but firmly sour with a nice drinkability.

[2369-20090801] Sample. Citrus lemon juice aroma. Murky, pale orange body with a quick bubbly white head. Pineapple and tart lemon juice flavour. Medium body. Interesting, good.
(BCTC @ Ommegang; Cooperstown, NY)

Big thanks goes out to puzzl and sonicdecent for this one. Big swirling pour. Pale color with just a hint of brown in there. Nice story on bottle.  Smell is fabulously tart and funky. Initial palate has very good tingle. Initially the taste is really enjoyable and sour, then it morphs, with each sip into something a little more bitter. Sour yes, but also malty and hoppy at the same time.  The bitterness does not override the session but fer certain it has its presence. Not a whole lot of funky in this brew, as with many real lambics. Hides the 6% alky content well. Bitterness keeps poking at the back of my throat after each slug.  At times, I think it is even getting bile-ish to an extent. Tho very sour & solid, Could have much less bitterness on the finish. I think, however, it was designed into the brewing of this beer. Very glad to have had the chance to taste this stuff, thanks guys!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Sampled from a 12 oz green bottle this beer poured a murky yellow color with a trace white head. The aroma was tangy, dryish, tart and citrusy with a spicy undertone. The flavor was tart, tangy and citrusy with a Sweettart candy element. The finish was long Sweettart candies. Medium body. Decent.

Had this one at the RB Pittsburgh tasting.  Brought it myself.  Was quite frightened after hearing this one may be too spicy, but those fears were put to ease when I finally got to try it.  Murky yellow pour, smell of great funk and light spice.  The taste was spicy, but not enough that it caused any issues.  In a perfect world, I would dial that down a bit, but this is still an extremely solid brew.

This one poured a cloudy whitish yellow color with a fluffy white head. Aroma was very tart, lemongrass and sour apples. Flavor was dry and tart, lots of lemon flavor almost like lemonade, but with a nice funky dank aroma.
batch #1   Tart apple skins, sweet malts on the nose.  Pours cloudy gold with no head.  Dry tartness, sour citrus fruits with some sour apricots, funky, tropical fruits.  Great!

Batch 3 - Thanks Sam! - Pours out a lt orange with a medium white head...aroma took a bit to figure out, passion fruit and guava, oak tannin and citrus zest...flavour is similarly tropical fruit up front, vinous tannin and tart oak round it out, spice and ginger have a slight presence as well mid palate...finish is spritzy and very tasty...

Batch 2. Holy crap this is a tasty, fruity, sour beer. Very unique appearance in that it reminds me of some squeezed grapefruit juice. Flavor is mostly tangy sourness with a little bit of citrus fruit and some green apple. Citrus is much more apparent in the aroma. Oak aging adds some depth to the flavor and chills all the sourness out a bit. Gives it some wood flavors working way in the background. On first sip you get some grapes and fruit up front but that fades into a sour tanginess that stays on your lips for a while. This one was memorable and still sticks in my brain at how awesome it was.

375ml bottle into tulip. 
Batch 3.

A - Pours a mirky yellow/orange color...reminds me of a mimosa. Very fizzy champagne-esk head. It quickly vanishes and leaves no lacing whatsoever. The beer looks flat (but isnt at all).

S - Tart lip-puckering sour notes. Sour apples, grapes, oak woodiness. Some sweetness in there as well, but nothing I can pick off the top of my head. Maybe some oranges or sweet cirtus of some kind, not exactly sure here.

T - Sour apples, grapes, oak. The sour and oak notes meld together well. A nice tart finish but not extreme like other examples of this style. Im really digging this one.

M - Light in body. Nice fizzy carbonation on the palate with a dry/clean finish. Like Ive said above, reminds me a lot of a fine champagne (in a good way). 

D - Super easy to drink. Light and refreshing. Glad I have more!

2009-08-01. First official beer of the fest, I lined up with a bunch of other eager souls waiting for them to start pouring. Ironically, a bottle sat half full for much of the night at the post-fest tasting while people attacked the plethora of rarities. Regardless, Im glad I got to it first thing. Murky pastel pineapple juice like body, tiny beige head. (3+) Strong aroma is funky, sour melange of pineapple and tropical fruit. (8+) Flavour is assertively sour, more sour tropical fruit character and a light funk, both of which are more restrained than I would have expected from the aroma. (7+) Average palate is lively and suits it well. Refreshing, very interesting. Bottle at BCTC 2009

375ml Bottle - huge thanks to Dickinsonbeer.  Cloudy gold, white head.  Nose is lots of pineapple, tangerine, some spice - not quite cardamom but something like that, along with some candied citrus fruits.  Flavor is tangerine, pineapple and lemon restrained by a very nice pils malt/light candy character.  Candied orange peel & pineapple acidity in the finish.

Batch 002, bottle. Pours a very light, peach color that is absolutely beautiful and Ive never seen in a beer. Aroma is very tropical and quite unique. Not too sour or funky, but the acidity is very nice. Flavor is strong and reminds me a bit of the temptation I just finished, with a lot of the muscat grapes coming through. Finish is very dry.
Hazy pale yellow, light fizzy head. Funky sour aroma. Very tart juicy nectarine sour flavor. Not overly aggresive. Slightly bitter finish. Very delicious.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2011 Corby112 shared at CCB.  Thanks Craig!! Damn fine beer!!  Cloudy yellowish pour, white head.  Tartness abounds in this one.  Green apples, green grapes, light vinegar, barnyard aromas and some light oaky notes.  Flavor is sour, but not to the point of pure vinegar.  Good fruit notes, especially some stone fruit and some lemony notes.  Good funky flavors...shit this is really good.  Thanks Craig!!!

(Batch #2)  Almost no head and no carbonation.  I expected this brew to be a foam monster.  Little bit worried now.  I guess that a sour beer really cant go that bad.  Strong aroma with lots of green tart apples, sourness, wet leather and I guess what some would call horse blanket (or sweaty farmyard animal).  Color is a clear bright yellow.  Light sourness that is not overpowering.  Just enough to make the mouth salivate constantly.  More green apples, lemon, tartness and white grapes.  Very reminiscent of a dry white wine.  Noticable alcohol presence that seems like more than the advertised 6%.  Finishes dry and tart and succulent.  A very good sour that is not over the top.  Better that I had initially expected.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2009 Time to catch up before BCTC. Bottle at PilsnerPeters Spring Throwdown. Thank to everyone who brought great beer and ribs and pickles and everything!  Pale yellow flat.  Hay barnyard horseballs aroma.  Barnyard citrus horseballs hay flavor.  Very nice, just wish it had a little carbo to blend everything.  Must try again........  

re-rate at BCTC.  Very tart funky dry with nice efferevescent carbo.  Carbo is the key to blending the flavors.  AWESOME.

Bottle courtesy of Dickinsonbeer. Shared with Rudolf, Jacob & IPFreely. Batch #3. Pours a cloudy hazed wit looking pale yellow. Big tropical fruit aroma. Peach, pineaplle & tangerine. Distinct funky sourness also noted. Taste is tart, mild funkiness & extremely fruity. Doesnt go overboard with the sourness but just enough. Great beer

batch 3...hazy golden pour with a quickly dissipating head...nose of grapes/apricots, good carbonation, perfect amount of sour kick, with a refreshing dry finish... thanks to #1 in line I was able to enjoy this beer.  I will be paying my dues next year

Batch #2.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy, pale yellow body with an initially large white head, though it soon dissipates. Though, even a modest swirl of the glass easily revives it.

Smell: Pleasantly scented nose of sweetish malts, lightly tart, well-oaked white wine, lavender, funky Brett notes, and with a distinct whiff of Matts 1978 Gas Line Lemonade.

Taste: Sweet pale maltiness alongside a sharp taste of lemon sherbet with a pop of bright acidity. Thin ripples of lavender. Muscat grapes marinated in white wine and honeydew melon juice laced with subtly funky flourishes of Brett. Zip of spicy oak character. Finishes dry, acidic, and with a final bump of tart fruitiness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Rather well carbonated.

Drinkability: Recommended. Cuvee de Castleton is good enough to run laps around most other beers.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2010 Bottle. Batch 3.Well after all the waiting this beer was well worth the waiting at the release. Golden pour with nice carbonation, watch out can be a squirter. This beer has great flavor and mouthfeel. The sour is not too tart and has flavors of grapes, malt, and the barrel makes it.

Bottle @ SDBF09. Batch 1. Enjoyed this version as well however perhaps passed its prime. More pineapple and grapefruit flavors apparent in this one. 4.1

wow thanx to Sammy for sharing this one

nose is tart but not to bad, some funky barnyard smell, bret is definatly there. hazy yellow color, little bit of foam. flavor was awsome definate Muscat grapes, and citric taste. sour and tart but drinkable, one of the best sour ales i have had

Bottle shared by an ever and always generous jrob21. Really nice to try this interesting sour. Golden yellow, small white head. Really intriguing aroma, slight funkiness, apricot, slight citrus.  Flavor is all that and more...funky sour, but not overly so. Some tartness, a variety of fruit with apricot predominating, also aspects of wine character, presumably from the grapes. Personally not a huge apricot fan, so that takes this beer down a notch or two, but awfully glad to have tried this thoroughly surprising beer.

pours golden with some sparkling head and body.  The aroma is complex, wine, champagne, malt, brett.  A full, aggressive on the palate mouthfeel - you get the brett and carbonation.  Muscat is right there - a quarter of it?  Best to share with friends, or if you have to, lots of different food, to mull it over. Not too sour, but sour.

750 ml bottle shared by eaglefan538... Cloudy white color??? Small head. Good aroma of grapes with a light floral note. Taste is the same lots of white grapes with a floral touch. Lots of carbonation on this one... Not super sour...more on the tart side....Really easy to drink and overall a really good beer... Thanks Brian for sharing this one

750ml bottle.  Pours a mostly clear golden yellow (looked like chardonnay) with a small bubbly white head.  Funky nose, at first reminded me of a lingering fart, that gave way to to champagne and apple cider tartness.  Flavor was tart with lemon, apple and sweet muscat grapes.  This bottle was about 10 months old, like to try a fresh one.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2009 Nose is of white wine, grapes, oak. 
Poured golden yellow with a small white head which falls and leaves little lacing. 
Taste has nice apricot, lemon, slight flavors of hay and earthiness and off putting herbs.

Bottle  Hazy, blond body.  Aroma of flowers, hops, grass, yeast, ...  Bit unbalanced, but very nice aroma.  Moderately bitter, lightly sweet flavour.  Bit watery, quite soft mouthfeel.   Nice, but not great.

Bottle. Cloudy yellow with a thin white head. Poor retention and lacing. Aroma is amazing and very complex. An interesting mix of wine and beer. There is Riesling, Gewurztraminer, star fruit, grapefruit, pear, pineapple, sourness, oak,  alcohol, lemon, spices and malt. Flavor is similar to the aroma with fruit salad syrup and warming alcohol. Full body. Not something I would have everyday, but a very interesting experience. The more beers I try, the harder it is to be surprised and amazed by a beer. This one did it for sure!

Bottle: Poured a cloudy dirty yellow color ale with a very small bubbly head with no retention or lacing. Aroma is quite complex with loads of musky white wine notes with some funky barnyard notes and a light oak and tart finish. Taste is very much complex with again some musky white wines notes with definitive Brett notes though not as much as expected and some tart finish with hints of oaks. I was expecting more sour character but still very much enjoy the final product. Body is full with limited filtration and not much carbonation with alcohol being very well hidden. Great experience and while not being an everyday kind of beer it is surely something I would wish to have more often.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2009 Batch #2 bottle thanks to glouglouburp! Hazy semi-opaque gold, small bubbly white head thats gone, and once its gone, it looks like piss. Really complex nose: sour grape and lemon, earthy, dusty, slightly stinky brett, and sweeter elements in pale, biscuity malt that are reminiscent of belgian ales. Even more tart flavor, which unfortunately washes out some of the complexity in the nose. More malt, some spice, a hint of barny brett, Very dry, only lightly carbonated, long grape and lemon finish. Really laid back sour, which allows a lot of elements to coexist. If only the flavor werent so citric heavy. Still, a superb nose and palate make this special.
Smells sour, lemon and apple. Pours yellow with white head. Taste is very appley, hint of vanilla sweetness, but really sour, Its also earthy, tastes like the woods.

Bottle of batch 2 at PilsnerPeters Spring Gathering.  Pours a hazy golden straw yellow with a thin white head.  Smells lovely with a nice brett funk and some clean candied citrus aromas. Thin to medium bodied.  Crisp citrus acidity.  Delicious.  Im eager for the next release this summer.

Bottle of the Batch #2.  Opens with a gusher.  Pours with a huge head that quickly dissipates. Lemony, vanilla-y, lightly spiced aroma.  Quite tart flavor with high carbonation evident in the mouthfeel.  This would probably benefit from a couple more years in the bottle.  Very good beer.

750ml. bottle.  This one was a gusher.  Poured a light yellow tan with an immense white head that lasted only seconds.  Winy, sour aroma with a pleasant hint of oak.  The flavor is very complex, with grape skins, key lime, buttery oak, sour green apple, and a hint of bready yeast.  The finish is crisp and sour but not overpowering.  I wish that there had been less carbonation as I thought it got in the way of this brews incredible flavor and overall experience.  Overall I was a bit disappointed, but it still is one delicious beer.

Bottle 75cl.[ As my Ratebeer rating #8000 ]. Clear sparkling medium to dark yellow color with a average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is acidic fruity - flowers - spicy, elderflower, grape (muskat grape), white wine, oak, citrus, very complex and nice aroma. Flavor is heavy sweet, acidc and sour - tart with a long duration, and a sour dry dry finish. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft to lively. This one is very nice ;O)) [20090116]

[Bottle] shared by tytoanderso. Pours a cloudy light gold with an effervescent white head. Aroma is light mineral water, funky yeast, and some lactic tartness. Flavor is lemony, gravelly with a light/medium sourness, and lots of bready yeast.

Bottle shared at crizays house

Thanks to Paul for cracking this open before the real tasting started.  If it had come out later I would not have appreciated it nearly as much.  From Batch 2 it has held up well in the time between bottling and now.

Aroma / Appearance - Cloudy and golden the fluid body hugged the curves of the glass.  Hazy and thick it released a nice mix of white grape, orange citrus, and dry champagne-like aspects.  Reminding me more of a wine than a sour ale it certainly is different from the norm.

Flavor / Palate - Grape, sourdough, and non-carbonated champagne fill the mouth with a dryness that leaves you wanting more.  This is one of the best sours I have tried although a few we opened later in the night blew even this away.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2009 375 ml bottle. At the Brewery! Advance tasting of 09 release. Bewwwwwww!
Bright sour full of fuity flavor! This beer will only get better with age.  


22oz bomber from my Beer Celler ྦྷ) Waited a long time to drink this and the wait was well worth it. I am not a sour man but this was a wonderfull mix of orange grapes lemons, with a very earthy finish. A sure winner! I liked this beer.

Batch 1. Did a hell of a lot of traveling for this bitch. Poured yellow with white head. Aroma of fruit. Grape, lemon, orange, and grapefruit flavor. Pretty sour. Amazing. Excellent. I know I made one person happy with this.

Not the gem I went in expecting, but still a solid slightly sour offering. Flavor had an almost buttery-ness to it and felt ever so slightly off.  Sour wasnt overpowering, and that I consider dissapointing.  Not bad, just not superb.

Golden-orange in colour with no head and no lacing.  The aroma is very acidic, sour with lots of citrus, green grape skins, cheese and green apples.  The flavour is sour with lots of green grapes, lemon citrus, high acidity, cheese, funky with some wood and earth.  Sour mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes very long with lemon citrus, sour.
This is pretty damn good stuff.  Has gueuze characteristics all throughout this.  Highly drinkable and right up there with the best sours from the US right now.
750ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheEpeeist, thanks Chris.
Opened on December 13, 2008.
Batch #2.
I think that Captain Lawrence is quickly becoming my favorite maker of sours.  This one is subtle, yet funky and well-blended in terms of flavor profile.  So good!

(bottle shared by tytoanderso, thanks Tyler!) Pours a hazed light yellow with a quickly disappearing white head.  Strong aroma of pinot gris, with oak, lemon peel, and a little bit of nail polish.  The taste is strong with mustard seed initially, but as the beer warms, more grapefruit and oak appear along with a taste that is reminiscent of mineral water.  At the end of the finish upon exhaling I also detected a faint cookie-like sweetness.  The mouthfeel was medium and the carbonation was spritzy.  This is pretty good.

Liquid gold upon first pour, hazy honey on second with a small ivory head and ample carbonation.  Aroma is sour grapes, rice wine vinegar, and lemon zest.  Extremely tart with a bit of sour funk, sweaty feet, and lemongrass.  Thin mouthfeel.  Not a bad beer but kind of expected more complexity.

Bottle graciously shared by the one and only BOLTZ7555  you da man J!  Pours a cloudy yellow with minimal head despite how carbonated it is.  The nose is lemon, light vinegar and malt.  The taste is lemon peel, white wine vinegar, light funk and sour grapes some light sweet malt in the background.  Lighter prickly mouthfeel.  Good stuff  thanks again J!

Thanks to rustychiles for the brew. Batch 02. Aroma of apples, pears, drywall, and perhaps some mild vomit. Appears to be a very light pils color with nice bubbling, yet no head. Taste is a very clean sour, lots of apples/pears/apricots and a very mild acid. Little bit of bite on the palate; quite cleansing and very nice, though I think it could have been more complex.

Batch 2 bottle via Miketd, thanks again ! Very clear dark gold with a fleeting white head. Nice aroma is mild barnyard with wood and white wine. Medium body with soft carbonation. Great flavor mirrors the aroma with white wine, wet wood, tart citrus fruit on a pale malt base. Mild to medium sour throughout. I need more of this brew, very nice.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
batch #2 rusty broke this out... unimpressed so i had to drink one alone. perhaps it was footy yelling at me?
pale golden pour with no head whatsoever. milkiness makes it almost white near the bottom of the glass.

surprisingly fruity aroma... until i remembered it had grapes in it!... green apples, grapes, cement/slate/minerals, spice and wood. 

the flavor doesnt pack that sour punch which most tend to possess. instead, it is very burgundian, subtle and refined... its more dry and bretty than sour with notes of green apples, green grapes/verjus, oak with just a touch of smoke and some spice on the finish. terribly easy to enjoy yet a bit too refined for this brute!... 8/4/8/4/17/4.1
EBF 09, Pours a hazy yellow with a small white head. Sour ale done right. Note of citrus,sour apples, oak and some pepper. I though this was one of the best of the fest.

Sampled at the Bockyhorsey tasting, courtesy of rustychiles.  Sparkling apple juice color pour with a small head.  Aroma of apples and grapes with a bit of funk.  Nice sour flavor with lots of fruit, yeast, a bit of wood and aspirin.  Nice sour lemon finish.  Very good brew!

Bottle, Batch #2 from iowaherkeye.  Pours a murky yellow and is almost fruit juice-like in appearance.  The beer is extremely unique and complex.  Starts out very sour and finishes with mix of citrus, funk, oak, and pepper notes.  It has some similarity to the bitterness of a white wine in the finish.   Very drinkable for the degree of sourness.  This is the first beer Ive had from these guys, and Im impressed.  I would definitely seek this out and try again.

Batch #1. Rating #1000 and the 200th rating of this beer. Picking out my 1000th rating was no easy task becasue my cellar has quite a few kick ass beers in it now thanks to the generosity of the traders from this site.I thought about doing some horrible NA beer or my old BMC swill staple Miller Lite. Perhaps a Scottish or Irish brew for my heritage or something from my homestate of NJ but alas I have no new Heavyweights to rate and did not bring back anything from my trip abroad a few years ago. I finally decided on this beer and I think it was the perfect choice. I bought this bottle during my first trip to a brewery, any brewery, ever. This also happened to coincide with Captain Lawrences 1st Anniversary party, my first ratebeer type gathering, and the first time Ive ever met anyone from this site in person. During this trip I met some of the areas most influential and active people from this site...EDA, meguair.. mkobes..to name a few. Of course this is when/where I met two of NJs RB elite whom I now consider my good friends Dickinsonbeer and willblake. (If I was the sentimental type this is where that little tear would form in the corner of my eye but luckily Im Scottish and other then anger and drunkenness my senses are dead.) The day ended with a stop off at Oak Tree Buy Rite on the ride home. The only way this day could have been better is if I could have stayed longer at the CL party. Now onto the beer:....Pours like a hazy champagne with a milky gold body and an ample bubbly mostly white head that once it disipates its gone, sort of like a young girls virginity. The aroma is funky, barnyard, sour white grapes, slight oak and some underlying smoke from the barrel. Palate is spot on with nice bubbly carbonation that fills your mouth as you swallow, but not overpowering, slight sourness on the finish yet very refreshing. Flavor is dominated by funkiness with the sourness kicking in nicely to remind you that this is no first timers beer. Citrus, sl
Thanks Rusty one of the best sours I had to rate so far. Good sour sweet fruity aroma. Clear gold with no head. Sweet citrus, acidic and sourness abound in this one. Palate says this one was good.

Bottle courtesy of Ty5592 and shared with the Phoenix crew at the Bockys.

Pours a nice hazy golden apple juice yellow with a small white head. Aroma of apple, grapes, funk slightly acidic. Flavor is sour, acidic, asprin, funk, grape. Nice carbonation,  good mouthfeel, good sour. Thanks Ty!

Batch 2. Very mild aroma of popcorn, sour fruit, oak and funk. Not a lot of complexity in the nose, or much vibrancy. Flavor is poorly balanced, harshly sour. Not much oak character at all or fruit. Very poor appearance, poorly lasting head and a gusher. I had batch 1 several times and didnt like it. I guess I just dont understand this beer. It doesnt seem to have much finesse.

750ml bottle batch 2 courtesy of Tayner. This immediately gushed but I didnt lose hardly any because I had my glass ready. Cloudy, dull yellow with a white head that disappeared instantaneously. The smell is faint and sour, spice, urine? Biting sour flavor with a slight hint of a lemon at the end and brett. Overall this was pretty sour but it didnt really hit the right note for me, maybe it needs more time in the bottle. The one thing I did really like about this beer is that it had the faintest taste of Capn Crunchs Crunch Berries, which was cool.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Bottle shared by Fonefan , thanks a billion - Batch 1 - Extremely beautiful clear deep golden body, lots of sparkle and a very beautiful white head; Extremely beautiful nose, super dense with super well put together aromas, the Muscat aromas are there clearly otherwise it is so well put together that it is quite hard to take apart, elderflower, citrus....very very well composed; Extremely fine body, overly complex, overly balanced and overly well put together, this beer is so well composed I have never tasted anything like it; It finishes long and extremely elegant. I dont know what to say, this is one of the finest beers I have ever tasted. Extremely well composed, I cant imagine any beer as fine. EXCELLENT!!!!!

Bottle, courtesy Kevin. Pours a cloudy chalky white, with hazy mango streaks and a white foamy head. Nose has a very tart punch, with sour, warm barnyard funk, and a splash of grapefruit in the end. Flavor is more of the same: tart and dry, with apricots, dry spices, grapefruit, hazy grapes, some banana in the finish. Very good. Dry, tasty, extremely easy to drink, incredible mouthfeel. One of the most interesting sours Ive had.

Thanks to Pantanap for sharing this.  Poured a hazy straw color with a dissipating white head.  The aroma was funk, grapefruit, hay, and some bitter herbs.  Taste was much the same, nice funky citrus, mainly grapefruit, with a balancing sweetness, spritzy carbonation and herbal hops on the end.  Solid sour.  Thanks kan.

Bottle courtesy of golubj.  Poured a clearer trhan expected, apple juice gold with a smallish white head.  Aroma was nice.  Sour grapes, oak, lemon and fruits.  Flavor improved with a bit of warmth.  Probably not on part with the ones I had last night.

Bottle, thanks to pilsnerpeter.  Clear pale gold pour, not much head, but some bubbles.  Aroma is tart, somewhat like white wine, a little lemony.  Flavor is subtly sweet at first, then grape-like sourness follows and wet wood.  The mouthfeel seems a little off, almost like apple juice.

Batch 2 bottle at Chris Os tasting, 26th Sept 2008, courtesy of HogTownHarry. This was scheduled to be my 1000th rating, but due to a miscalculation, it turned out to be my 999th, which is kind of fitting as it was a bit of a disappointment given its reputation. It is a pretty restrained sour with a yeasty, winey taste and a decent fruity, slightly citrus aroma. Yeasty finish. Enjoyable but not outstanding.

750, corked and baled. Thanks, BVC! Very nearly the beer of the night. Batch 2. Cloudy light yellowish toffee color. Headless, laceless. Big tart lemon and vinegar nose. Very pleasant, though--not by any means the sourest beer around. Fizzy medium body with minerals, lemon, white vinegar, and a big lactic kick. Very drinkable. Delicious.

Sampled on 12/12/2008. This sour ale pours a light gold color from a 750ml bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity, grapey, a touch tart and a little funky. A medium to light bodied sour ale. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are floral. Kind of a subtle and delicate beer, from the subtle nose to the dry and bretty finish. There is a touch of grape throughout. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter and very dry.

Batch #2. Pours a brilliant  cloudy orange color. Little to no head at all. Aroma is light and tart full of citrus\lemon. taste is vinus and grapey, with a fruity funky aftertaste and  oaky undertone. an interesting delicate beer.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Pours with a slightly cloudy orange yellow body topped a thin head with some lacing.  It is sour and tart with a very slight funk and a note of lemony citrus.  Light bodied, dry and smooth.
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2009 Pours golden orange, tart, grapes, grassy, little citrus, little yeast, little wood.  Rerate Nov. 25th- CO2, Pineapple, spice, clean finish.  Thanks Cloudskipper!

Pours beautiful bright golden orange with a fizzy thin off white head. Everything about this one is delicate, from the nose to the finish. Light grapes and brett make up most of the nose and flavor. Oak like finish.
Courtesy of BDR.  Cloudy yellow color with no head.  Light tart aroma.  The taste is wicked... sour honey, wheat, and just enough dull hops to be noticed.  Not mouth-puckering at all.  Sublime.

750ml bottle, Batch 2. Thanks to GlouGlouburp. Pours slightly hazy pale yellow with no head. Smells of grapes and vinegar a bit of earth and straw as well. Tastes nice and sour with lots of grape flavor, good acid but not instant heartburn. A bit of hay flavor. Very nice, not to aggressive. Just a touch of wood, tastes like new oak to me. Medium body, good carbonation.

Batch 2 bottle shared by Crosling.  Poured a bright straw yellow color with a thin white head that diminished to nothing.  Sweet, citric aroma with hints of lemon, tart grapefruit, some light peach and a bit of funky yeastiness.  Tart, moderately fruity entry with some barnyard yeastiness and a moderate lemon flavor with a bit of tart grapefruit and just a faint hint of oak.  Low carbonation and a tart bite.  I agree with Mes, definitely one dimensional, there didn’t seem to be any nuance or balance to this brew at all, it was just a lemon bomb with an awkward off taste.  I didn’t detect any grapes, and the oak was faint to barely recognizable.

A Mes rate: bottle at the Harry vs Wolfman fist fight.I have to be honest, this is not a good looking beer. A pale dirty yellow brown with a white head that vanished almost instantly. Full on lemon aroma, there is some excellent barrelly sourness and wooden notes but it’s completely overridden by the citrus. The flavour is similar. Just way too much lemon. To be honest, it’s a bit of a charlatan if you ask me. It’s just a pretty standard blonde with lots of tarty lemon added. It seems to be the only source of acidity and tartness. Even the dryness feels forced. The finish is excellent but it’s just lemon again. Don’t get me wrong this is a nice beer all round (apart from the looks) but it’s certainly one dimensional and rated far to high if you ask me.

Thanks to luttonm for the taste. Pours incredibly light - almost like a Belgian wit bier - with a small head that fizzles to nothing. Aroma is very tart, with lemon and grapefruit, and a little funk, too. Flavor adds some depth, with yeast - somewhat like a saison. The muscat grapes come through as well (those are fantastic grapes). Very tart - almost candy tart - but I can certainly see this being one I’d like better every time I got the opportunity to try it. A treat, for sure.

750ml (batch 2) thanks MaxxDaddy. Clean, champagne like pour. Looks, smells and first taste is of lemon juice. Utterly tart and keeps going far longer with the sour than most anything I’ve had. Crisp, strong taste of moist citrus and lemon. Dry, long finish with some yeasty/farmhouse notes. Yesterday I woke up sucking on lemons.
very nice

Batch 1, aged about 1.5 years.  Courtesy Morgan from Great Orlando Beer Festival. Holy Mother is this beer fantastic!  The body is a cloudy, glowing, yellowish-tangerine color.  A tiny white cap of foam recedes quickly to a swirly film, minimal, spotty lacing marking the glass.  Tiny, effervescing streams of micro-bubbles pool into the surface of what otherwise might resemble some sort of tropical fruit punch.This might very well be the best smelling beer I have ever come across.  Fresh, tart, citric grapefruits, both ruby red and standard white varieties, take center stage.  Ascorbic lemon enters the fold, followed by tart peach, sweet mango, and hints of orange peel.  Signature French oak and mildly funky, wild yeast finish off the nose, which ultimately comes off as a beautiful hybrid of tropical Sauvignon Blanc, Muscat, and sour ale.Its hard to imagine a flavor that could match the sweet symphony of aromas that this beauty emits, but this one achieves it.  Somehow, puckering tartness and fruity, tropical sweetness strike a perfect balance.  Theres so much funky fruit going on here, its hard to take it all in.  Sour grapefruit, sweet-tart peach, mango, Muscat grapes, and perhaps even some pineapple all shine.  The barrel influence is just right, imparting a very wine-like feel to the end product, while the wild, funky yeast lets you know it is ale.Ultra-fine, Champagne-like carbonation tickles the tongue ever so gently after each breathtaking sip.  The light, vinous body is so refreshing, it is incredible.  Dry, ascorbic, puckering and soft, this simply begs to be drunk.Quite simply put, this beer is world-class.  Period.  Point blank.  WORLD CLASS.  Easily one of the best ales I have ever laid nose or lip to.  I can hear Batch 2 calling out to me from the cellar, tempting me, daring me to drink it.  It is taking every ounce of restraint I can muster to wait for the right time to crack that bad boy open.
Cloudy yellow color.  Grapes, sour grapefruit and vanilla flavors are the most prominent with the Sour Patch Kid pucker-up goodness.  This is my perfect beer...
Batch #1. Yeasty and cloudy pale yellow. Sweet and tart, almost candyish. Grapefruit sour juice.  Lightly vinous.  Light in palate and ultimately very drinkable and complex. Damn.

Batch 002

It pours almost no head with a carbonation like soda pop and a clear yellow color. The smell is slightly sour with some white wine characteristics and dry bouquet. Taste is a dry white wine with some subtle sour flavors in the background. Still a good mouthfeel with carbonation not overpowering, but giving a good soft acidity. Overall, it’s pretty easy to drink as it’s a good palate refresher and easily should pair with intense food flavors.

Bottle at the Angry Fist of Santa tasting at Chris_o’s.  Hazy pale gold, very lemony tart aroma.  Bleachy lemon.  A bit like a lemony saison.  It’s quite a good balanced sour beer.  Good palate and good lemon finish.

Bottle.  At Chris_O’s September 2008 DenCan bash.  Last beer of the night, everyone was stoked for this, but ....  Pale cloudy yellow with minimal head - not very appealing (3-).  Aroma of lime, oak resin and sweet malt, almost over-balanced by sour lemon.  The taste broke down to simple sour lime juice with a little woodiness - where’s the yeast, bitterness, ANYTHING else?  Light of body, serciously acidic and still, with an almost puckeringly sour/dry aftertaste.  I wanted to love this one, and I like me a sour beer, but no way in HELL what I drank is in its wildest dreams near a 4.  Thanks for the share guys - great tasting and I hope to see you all next year.

Bottle at chris_o’s wolf slapping, harry bashing, royal teabagging tasting. Bottle to celebrate my 4000th rating, many thanks to the American chap who supplied it! Alround rating: Strong coconut, spice and yeastyness, lemon, vinigar, cereal malts, floral hops. I was really looking forward to this, however was a bit suprised by how it turned out as it was drinkable enough but a bit boring for me. Ah well iv got alot more to look forward too!

Bottle @ Chris_os Pre-Beer Exposed Tasting, September 2008.
Pours muddy, pale yellow with nearly no head. Aroma is tart citrus and oranges. Okay, dryish mouthfeel. Flavour is softly tart, a bit of wood. Very citrus-oriented if not one-sided. There are so many (much) better sours around.

Had it at a tasting at Whole Foods Bowery. A really interesting beer... lighter than most other sour ales, it had a nice sweet side, with peaches and hints of orange. A really cool variant of one of my favorite beer styles. I’ll be looking to get more of this one.

bottle-pours a white ring and cloudy yellow color.  Aroma is tart lemon/apple, yeast, light malt.  Taste is very tart lemon/apple, yeast, light malt, vanilla, oak, pepper, some vinegar.  Occasional, quite interesting although not my taste.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2010 Light hazy gold, large head that makes a lot of noise and dies really quickly, leaving nary a wisp behind.  Nose is first of brett, champagne yeast, and some vague sparkling light fruits.  Theres a burst of white grape, its definitely that and its really developed, one of the strongest fruit characters in any beer Ive had.  The oak is really nice and subtle, perfectly dry.  Prickly mouthfeel.  The finish is ridiculously long -- on an aside I went to the release and had a single sip out of a glass there, and I literally could still taste the flavor evolving 20 minutes into the car ride home.  Really a pefect, wonderful sour character, not overly so, but really elegant and refined.      Bright, clean, crisp, really awesome.

Bottle from PUB’N via Capone’s.  Pours chill hazy gold with medium, fixxy off-white head and a lot of carbonation streams.  Nose is earthy sour mashy, grapey, with notes of pear, yeast, spice, and citrus.  The palate is lively, dry champagny, not as complex as Cantillon offerings, but not as mouth puckeringly tart either.  Gets a bit sweeter as it warms, with more grapey flavor, and remaninign champagny throughout.  Very good, but not worth the very high black market price I paid.  I like the CL Smoke from the Oak and Winter Warmer much better.

Tasting at PP C-Bad, thanks to wetherel! Cloudy light yellow hue with no head. Nose is super sour tartness, apples, pears, grapes, oak, pepper, spices. Taste is mouth-puckering sweet tarts, transition to sweet grapes and light fruits, finishes dry and bubble like champagne. Slick texture with high carbonation. Amazing sour ale with great texture and fruit presence, definitely top tier here!

Thanks for sharing a bottle, beastiefan2k. The body was hazy medium yellow. The aroma was bretty with some funky pears and cobwebned cellars. The taste was tart apricots with some hay. There was also some flowers to complement the sourness. A nice clean finish. A little boring and underwhelming.

Many thanks to iowaherkeye for bringing this bottle to his farewell to Iowa tasting. Batch 2. Poured a hazy yellow color with a white head that reduced to a soapy ring. Attractive aroma of buttery oak, white wine vinegar, and a dash of spices. There was mild acidity up front that waned toward the end giving way to some delicate sweetness. Tasted of lime peel, pale malts (ala cereal grain), unripe apple, and a splash of vinegar. Almost Key Lime Pie-ish. Delicious.
Lemon yellow pour with a thin white head.  Aroma is lemons and dust.  Flavor was oak, grape tannins, lemon, limes, pepper,  and a bit of funky dust.  Lightly sour finish.

Thanks to Ken for this one.  Cloudy yellow, no head.  Aroma has a sour lemon note followed by a hot spicy pepper quality.  Flavor is not tart enough for me but has a nice lemony touch, yeasty spice bite, vinous notes, and pineapple.  Not quite dry enough.
Bottle. Aroma is funky brett, wonderful fruitiness, light oak. Taste is light fruit, onion skin, funky barnyard, and a pleasant sourness. Very nice!

Tasted at Cleveland tasting on 8-23-08.  Thanks!!  Batch 2 was poured.  Pours a cloudy yellow color with a off white head.  Has a lot of citrus on the nose.  Has a medium body.  Taste is lemon, yeasty, crisp finish, and overall has a fruity finish.  This is a nice brew.  Perhaps not as good as what I’ve tried so far this tasting.  But it can stand alone on its own as a solid sour.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2008 Batch 2, via trade with JoeMayo on BA. Pours a murky yellow- gold color, capped with a small off-white head and effervescent body. Aroma is musty and lactic, with notes of white grape, lemon, oak and some wild yeast. Flavor is as complex as the aroma, with white grape, lemongrass, citrus, wild yeast, and some oak. Long, moderately tart finish.  Its not as lactic as some other sours, adding to its drinkability. I had this with a variety of cheeses, and it nicely complimented nearly all of them. The active carbonation seemed to clean the palate. This is a beautiful beer; I need to get more!

Bottle shared with emagee’s 1,000th rating.  Thanks, Ethan!  Light, bright golden color.  Very slightly hazy.  Nose of muscadine, lemony-citrus, lemongrass, apricots, peaches, floral notes, and a tart yeastiness.  More bready/yeasty on the palate than expected, losing some of the fruit tartness, but still very good with a dry crisp finish.  Delicious.

Shared by that dude below, on his 1,000 rating. Thanks, Ethan! Smells a bit like finger? Oh wait, that’s the wrong rating. The pour reminded me almost of a gueze, insofar as it was much more bright and clear than expected. Champagne-like carb for sure, with a lovely head. Dry and oaky aroma comes across initially, quite inviting. As you get into the beer, the muscat grapes are everywhere, not in an overpowering sense at all, but in a nicely suffused, well integrated sense. Light floral notes in there to balance things out, and it’s got a deliciously dry finish too. Very fine, and big thanks again to Finger Man.

Thanks to hophead75 for this one. Andrew graciously traded me one of his two bottles for my 1000’th rating. Here goes. Pours a very bright clear pale yellow. Has very large carbonation and sits effervescent in the glass, very champagne like. The head was kind of profuse but subsided very quickly and very loud. The nose was very prominent with white muscat grapes (and hand), a nice tart fruitiness that isn’t overly prominent, very yeasty and a soft oakiness. The flavor is very vinous, spicy oak, yeasty, the tart/sour character isn’t dominating and plays a nice complimentary role in the beer. The grapes and spices show also show well. Very lively and exciting mouthfeel, the carbonation is very tactile and the overall body of the beer does not disappoint either. Overall, this was a great sour and its individual aspects melded well rather than any one dominating. Just what I like in a sour, balanced complexity.

I hope nobody minds this placeholder rating for the purposes of the DD Top Ten list accuracy. l’ve got a real rating somewhere, and l’ll enter it one of these days, but for now l hope it’s enough to say that one of the bottles I had of this was one of my favorite beers of all time. Batch 1, because of its incredible tropical fruit medley.  Batch 2 unfortunately doesn’t come close, for me.  Yet.

Rating #1000.

Ive been saving this one for a special occasion, and rating #1000 seems as good an occasion as any. It opens with a puff and begins slowly gushing foam until I pour it out hazy and golden, with more large clumps of orange-ish floaty material than I would like to see. Fascinating nose: the muscat grapes come on strong here, lots of passionfruit and some pineapple, golden raisins. Flavor like scooping passionfruit seeds out of a fresh fruit that has been drizzled with lemon juice, quite strongly acidic but not overly so. And then chardonnay-like oak and grapes adding complexity, plenty of sweetness (but not enough to make this a sweet-tart sour) to keep things diverse. It took my palate eight ounces or so to adjust relative to the dry, minerally, lactic beers Ive been drinking, but now that Ive  made the switch this one is really coming off as very good. Unfortunately, as it warms there is this rancid mandarin orange thing going on that is not a virtue, and near room temperature that almost dominates. . Light and refreshing (though never watery) on the tongue, great lemon close. Its a very different beer from sour gems coming off the West  Coast, but once one puts those expectations aside this thing is an artwork in its own right.

Batch 02 at RBSG. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Great perfumy aroma of citrus and lemon rind. Starts off with tart citrusy flavors, and has more white grape and peppery wood flavors mid palate. This acidity is just right for me. Not being overly acetic or lactic on the finish makes this one easy to drink. Overall this is well-balanced and stellar brew. Ross probably thinks I should not rate this one either since I did not drink it straight from the storage tank.
Thanks to JoeMcphee for this one !  Cloudy straw pour, minimal head if any.  Citrus tart on the nose.  Very acidic with notable hints of oak, grapes and brett.  Crisp finish, but not too dry

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 Thanks to Drink4satan and Emerica56 for this awesome treat. Pours a hazy straw color with no head and mild carbonation. Aroma of salty, funk,  citrus, grapes. Initial taste is salty, sour and lots of citrus rhine. Mid palate of grapes and oak. Finishing continuing rhine bitterness and nice funk. Palate duration is above average. Light bodied and very easy drinking. Very refreshing and absolutely delicous. Acidity is lower than expected but still very good for a sour ale.

Thanks to Drink4Satan for giving me a bottle drink on my birthday. The color is a cloudy orange and yellow,it almost looks like orange dry soda. The nose is very salty with hints of some lemon grass. As you take a drink it you can taste the saltness and clearly tell that the acidity is much higher then most beers. I personaly like the sour after taste that is left on the side walls of your mouth, it reminds me of a sweet tart. The carbonation it just perfect for this beer.

Much thanks to Dmac for this one. Pours out a nice slightly cloudy golden/yellow color with a very small head. Aroma is vinous and is of grapes, brett and some oak. Flavor is very complex and wonderfully balanced. Grape, oak, brett, citrus tartness and slight yeast make this all come together very well. Excellent beer and once again thanks to Dmac.

750 ml bottle batch 2.  Pours a cloudy honey yellow gold with a medium sized white foamy head.  Aroma of funk, lemon tart, grapes and wine.  Taste is funky with a strong lemony tartness and hints of grapes and fresh yeast.  As it warms, the oaked wine barrel flavors come out.  Nice.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2008 Color is pale yellow with fizzy bubbly head.  Taste is sweet and tart, with a somewhat dry finish.  Lemons and citrus favors full throughout.  Nice easy drinking beer, highly recommended to the sour heads out there.  Winner in my book

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2010 batch 2
Aroma is very lactic and sour.  Lots of lemon and some bitterness.  
Pours hazy, piss colored.
Taste is slightly bitter, very subdued, lemony and well-balanced.  
Finishes kind of dull and not nearly as sour as I would expect.  
Dull, grapey flavor, lemon, sour and subdued and oaky.  
Nice, but not overwhelming.  Complex, but not as world-class as I would think by the ratings.
I think the understated nature of this beer is what is getting people.  Has a load of complexity, grapes, sourness, oak, everything.  
Its growing on me.  847516
----- Batch 3 consumed relatively fresh------- is very intense muscat grape and residual sweetness, funk, horse, citrus, honey suckle....
Taste is a bit flabby, sweet and sprite with some mouth puckering sourness, muscat grape, and funk.
Finish is still a bit sweet, more grape, and some acidity.  
Needs a few years.  Rating unchanged

Bottle from the brewery on the release day. It smelled incredible, so much going on, it was wonderful, definite sour smell, the taste is fruity but tart with some spice and a lot going on. I don’t really know much about sour ales and probably wouldn’t buy this again or drink again by choice but it is an incredibly complex beer that I would love to try again once I’ve learned more about sours.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text:
UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Bottle, batch 2 sampled the day of the release.  Pours a cloudy light orange with a fizzy white head (careful when opening!).  Aroma of tart sour fruits (apple, pear), oak/barrel, and some grapey wine notes, especially as the beer warms.  Flavor of sweet tart oak, same fruits as in the aroma.  I have to admit that I havent been impressed with some of Captain Lawrences special release beers, but thankfully this beer lived up to its reputation and more!  An awesome sour, super drinkable, very complex and interesting.  Excellent and well crafted.
Update 7/27/2009.  Batch 3.  Aroma is super lemony and citrus, perhaps there are some grapes in there too.  Flavor is funky and sour upfront with a wheaty finish.  Not as fruity as the aroma (although still fruity).  Very drinkable as well.  Very very similar to Batch 2 I think.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2009 batch 3 bottle the same stellar beer! wonderful aroma that has a little less of the sweet grape but more funk and sourness. leans a little more dry but waters the mouth with amazing flavors. still fantastic for me and the carbonation is spot on. 

750 bottle batch#2 picked up fresh today at the release. poured a slightly hazed yellow golden color with small bubbles of light carbonation when swished in the glass. aroma has plenty of horse blanket, sour white grapes, underlying citrus peels, dry white wine, and a touch of wood and wine from the barrels. simply unbelievable what the wood and brett does to this one. mouth feel is smooth and light with just enough carbonation to push it across. flavor shows off the white grapes up against the sourness from the brett, oak lies in the background, light spices,  horse blanket, touch of citrus, and an almost creamy richness. this pulls the taste in so many directions, sweet, sour, and dry. finish goes dry with a lingering white grape and sour punch. this is so well balanced and drinkable. i have to admit i drank the first bottle of the four all to myself.

Bottle, Batch 2 fresh from the brewery. Aroma of sour green grapes, horseblanket funk (distinct yet relaxed and pleasant), liquoricy funk, lemon/pineapple. Flavor definitely retains those tart grapes and has some interesting tart herbal qualities. Unbelievably drinkable, fairly laid back carbonation after the pour, little to no vinegary aspects, clean finish. An absolute pleasure.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2008 Bought four bottles at the brewery today! Pours a translucent yellow/cream colour with a wispy white head that leaves minimal lacing. The nose ruminates from the glass, leding to impressions of horseblanket, sharp citrus, sour white grapes, ultra-funky Brettanomyces, wood and acetic acid. The flavour is sharp, tart and funky, with some residual bitterness in the finish. Notes of lemon, barnyard funk, tart grapes, cardamom? and loads of Brett yeast. The sourness is less harsh than the Cantillion classic Gueuze, making it far more drinkable than many Belgian examples. There is a creaminess to the palate, which nicely counters the sharp, sour flavours. It is softly, yet amply carbonated. Another magnificent brew from a great brewery.
I love sours and this was a good one that was funky yet had that nice sour taste to it and tart,it poured a nice yellowish color and was smooth in the finish very enjoyable.CHEERS!

Bottle, thx Omhper!  Lemon-yellow colour. Bright carbonation. Sharp tartness. The sourness in this beer rivals that of many Belgians. Once again, top notch - thx Omhper for getting your hands on gems like this (and sharing them !).
An old rating i finally got to entering. Aroma was of some tart fruit and spices. Flavor was of spiced and maybe some grape. Tart and left  a sweet tart feeling on the top of my mouth.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 Bottle sampled at blind tiger with BrianK.  This was the first time that i truely enjoyed drinking a sour ale.  A light yellow with darker hues and a light head.  Aroma is sour grapes, oak, acidity in your nostrals, light fruit lemony citrus.  Has a dry mouth puckering sourness that is reminicent of apples and grapes, woodiness in the flavor helps to balance this one out.  A very enjoyable sour, i cant wait to have batch 2.  4.3
Batch 3 is getting better and better.  4.4
Somehow ive got to sample 3 bottles of the Batch 1 already in 2011 and i have to say its freaking stellar.  Bumping this up big 4.7-4.8 (For batch 1).

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2008 Batch 1:
Bright yellow color with quickly receding white head, little lacing.  Aroma has lemon, oak, somewhat acidic, pineapple, and some chardonnay.  Taste is quite acidic, but full of interesting flavors like oak, lemon, hay, chardonnay, and pineapple.  Very dry and light on the palate with fairly high carbonation.  A very, very good sour.


Batch 2:  Yellow with a white head that dissipates fairly quickly, leaving no lacing.  Oak in the aroma, along with some lemon and other citrus aromas.  Not very intense, rather delicate, but interesting and well done.  White wine taste, lemon tartness, oak, peaches, and maybe a hint of apricot.  Medium carbonation and light body, finish is fairly dry.  Not nearly as sour as the first batch, but it has nice flavors and is still a nice sour.  4 - 9 - 9 - 4 - 17 = 4.3

Sampled at HotShotz Indy tasting May 24, 2008 - Aroma is spicy yeast, lemon, oak, white wine, apple and ripe melon.  Pours cloudy yellow with a ring head and decent lacing.  Flavor is very similar to aroma with a great sourness added to it.  Citrus, oak, spice and wine.  Palate is tart but clean.  Super smooth and tasty, I could drink this everyday.

Thanks for bringing this to the tasting sprinkle. I got an end pour, so my sample was pretty cloudy, it is easy to arouse some head, err... White wine grapes in the nose, the label says Muscat. You know it will be sour from the smell. 
  And it is, more acetic than the aroma led me to think. Great wine flavors, the oak is soft. Mouthfeel is soft, although well carbonated, the bubbles are small and tight. I could easily polish off a couple bottles this was easier to get.

A  750 ml  bottle (batch # 1) to celebrate our 10th marriage anniversary. Blonde, no head, cloudy. Grapes, traubenzucker, leather and lemon in the complex aroma. Muscat grapes, oak, grapefruit and lemon in the sour flavor. hardly any rest sugars, just dry, tart and fruity. oak especially noticeable in the vinous finish. I just love this brew, however Diane took a few sips and emptied a glass of water immediately afterwards. Thanks, Dickinsonbeer, for this very special beer!

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2013 750mL Bottle. Batch Number 1. Wildly complex nose. Lavender and pink peppercorns immediately come to mind. Dry oak is definitely present. Somehow Im transported to the Sycamore canyons of southeastern Arizona. Musky and fruity. Complex and unique. The beer pours a raging, lightly hazed golden. Prickling with carbonation and producing a white head that behaves weirdly. It holds at first and then subsides quickly into the beer, leaving nothing behind. Clean. At first, Im mulling on these flavors and wondering why this is so highly regarded. Is my palate missing the boat here? I give it time. I mean, its a vibrant, brightly flavored fruity dry beer, with unique character and nice acids. The grapes are what really end up doing it. There is certain white grape fruit juice, but its more refined. In a white port kind of way. A bit of apple juice takes me to the vineyards of Switzerland and I imagine the sun is warming my face. This is a really interesting beer. Lightly sweet, with apple juice and white grape character, showing an oaked finished and very clean acids. Mature and refined. I would never expect a beer to really behave this way, like wine. And maybe thats why Im struggling with it a little. This may have crossed the line for me a little bit. My second pour from the bottle is insanely cloudy. The first was brilliantly clear. The carbonation must have brought a lot of yeast up. The beer develops some more softness, light spice and general fruitiness. White figs play a role at this point. This beer is refreshing and delicious. Theres a harder-to-describe vibrant fruitiness riding over the top of this beer that I cant quite latch on to. Okay, this beer is awesome. The bright, fresh acids, the balanced sweetness, the oak, the finish in complex, spicy fruits, and the carbonation. I just dont want to put the glass down, its too good. Dry. Its not so much that any single element of this beer is ragingly amazing or unique, but that the beer as a whole is rather perfect and delightful. The grapes certainly give it panache, but the real excellent here is in how clean and fresh the acids blend with the beer. Nice job Scott. More: Im not giving this beer enough credit. It really is pretty phenomenal. One reason is that the barrel influence is perfect and thats hard to accomplish. Also, the flavors are just sustaining, like nothing else. This is world class.

Was lucky enough to try a bit of this at Flossmoor before DLD, and thanks to whoever it was that allowed me a sample, as Ive forgotten...  Poured a hazy yellowish color.  Smell was tart, smooth, mild funkiness.  Taste was smooth, slightly funky and deliciously tart and drinkable.  Reminded me of beatification, but even slightly more smooth and drinkable.  Nice sour grapefruit flavor.  This was quite good.

Pours a very cloudy yellow with a small foam ring. Very sour, pungent aroma. Wow! Muscat grapes. Lots of citrus in the flavour - interesting... lemon and apples, plenty of astringent notes. Good carbonation. I dont like sours much but I liked the citrus character in this one - very compelling.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 Sweet Jesus! Finally!  Ive been trying to get my hands on this one for a while. It is every bit as good as I had hoped. 
Heavenly aroma. Tart, fruity and funky all at once. The brett is beautiful. Pineapple, white grape skin, new oak. Absolutely intoxicating aroma. Pours a bright, cloudy yellow with a thin ring of a white head. Loads of bretty tartness on the palate. Quite crisp and refreshing. Almost gueuze-like in its funk, but not as intense. Lemon zest, lots and lots of white grape skin, oak tannin... theres enough of a malty base, though that holds down the funk. Lively and vibrant on the tongue. Mildly tart and acidic finish with some lemon zest sourness that lasts forever... Insanely drinkable for how massively complex this beer is. Top notch and superb all the way! Thank you ever so much for your wonderful generosity Ken!
Re-rate. 10/11/08 Everything about this beer is magical and transcendent. Its radiant and glowing color. The beautifully tart, funky and insanely complex aroma. The taste sends goosebumbs up and down my spine. Wickedly complex and utterly drinkable. Everything... malt, yeast, hops, barrel... is in perfect harmony. Ripe and prickly mouth feel with a finish that goes on forever. I cant see how beer can possibly get better than this. A true experience for the senses. Truly a masterpiece. 
March 09 batch 2. Less acidic. Less barrel and a much flabbier and less snappy body. Lacks the vibrancy of batch 1 and other batch 2s. Hmmm...
May 09 batch 2. The last 2 bottles Ive opened have been a bit "off" but this last one is back... spot on! Amazing acidity and seems to be drying out quite a bit. Full mouthfeel and a wonderfully lengthy finish. Cant wait for batch three!
Another Batch 2 May 09. Out of a cardboard cup in Northern Minnesota while camping with the family. Still insanely delicious. Getting more and more tart the longer the bottles age. 

 Unfortunately, have to dock it .1 because some (not all, and not that many) of the batch 3 and batch 4s have been a ***bit*** off. Slightly flabby mouthfeel, musty nose and lacking the amazing zestiness and crispness of "on" bottles. Still amazing, but consistent bottles are a must for a perfect 5.

Grapefruits, grapes and berries in the sour nose along with a jolt of alcohol. Hazy yellow-blonde body is topped by a decent white head that recedes to a ring and partial cover with some spotty lacing.  Flavour offers apples, pears and grapefruit with a wine-like character.  Very dry, somewhat astringent and puckering.  Sharp pointy carbonation.  Bottle sampled at Oakes Xmas tasting 2007.

Bottled. Thanx omhper.  Hazy pale yellow with fizzy head. Great, and new to me, sorbet like aroma with exotic fruits (you name em all) with bit of yeast and earthiness. Great mouthfeel, with fizzy carbonation with exotic fruits - all you can think of - plus tutti frutti, pear, grape... this is a very complex brew indeed with accompanying tartness that seems so perfect. Fantastic beer!

750 ml bottle. Yellowish cloudy and white. Initial head then it falls down quickly leaving next to none. Refreshing yeasty sourish and acidic flavours. Tart. Lambic aromas. Mellow acidic sourish lemony flavours balanced by a soft powdery texture. Very refreshing. Wonderful beer. Long-lasting sour finish.

Small fizzy white head that dissipates quickly with no lace happening. Hazy, blond body. Nose is expansive,  spicey and fruity, even at a distance yer catching notes of citrus, light vinous notes, apples yeast and a light mustiness. Body is light with a prickly carbonation and a light oilyness, Light citrusy notes of lemon/lime, clean wet leatheer notes, faint lumber,grapes, apples and brett. Tart on the palate, very cleansing and awakening. Dry, fruity and tart finish. A really neat treat! Cheers to eaglefan for sharing, thanks Brian!

Bottled (thanks omhper!). Hazy yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, hops, yeast and some caramel & earth in a wellbalanced mix. Flavour is sour fruits, some wood and acidic notes. Some tropical fruits lurking in the background balancing it up to a refreshing brew.

Bottled, thanks to omhper. Pours out in a very hazy pale yellow with a small white head. Extremely tart of lemon and horse blanket. Tart and really dry flavour of grapefruit, brett, lemon-rind, stable and hay with a a whiff of acidic tropical fruit. Puckering tart long finish of grapefruit, green apples mild wood and plenty of brett. Wow, simply fantastic!

Bottled, thanks kmweaver!  Pours lively hazy pale yellow with brief fizzy head. The nose is tart and vinous. Its dry, and citric with barnyard, grape and wood. Fresh and lively, complex and just wonderful. Has the qualities that makes it stand out even in the toughest crowd. A superb beer!

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2009 Original rating: Bottle from jjpm74, a very generous dude. The pour was hazy golden in color, head initially pretty spritzy, gushing, quickly diminishing to a thin head to nothing. Aroma is super aromatic, smelled far away from the bottle, in the glass though a nice blend of grapes, sour citrus, and wood notes. Funk and horse blankets pretty soft, though. The flavor was muscrat grapes with lemon tartness, bret notes, finishing with a yeasty bready malt support that was pretty phenomenal. I love the malt support in these sours, and this didnt take the amber to brown track, but sure was enjoyable. Mouthfeel was spritzy, pretty drinkable within style. Thanks, John, and great sharing w/ ya, Bert. Woo hoo! Re-rate, bottle from Cletus, as beer number five in a killer July 09 Super Secret Sour State Line Tasting (SSSSLT) featuring (first to last by my counts): Supplication, Consecration, La Folie, Dissident, Cuvee de Castleton, Red Poppy, Lambic de Hill, Festina Lente, Panil. Bottle opened and white grapes jump out, strong pop sound. Spices in the finish with some cellar-mustiness. Floral notes alongside this one too. Excellent, well done, a novel brew, props points for the originality. Pretty drinkable, hardly that sour/tart after all these others in this run. Thanks, John!

Grapefruit and yeast aroma and taste with a dry finish.
Cloudy golden yellow; white head.  Funky fruit aroma.  Flavors are of funky fruit, passion fruit, lemon, pepper, red wine, wood, earth.  Strange, complex and tasty.

Pours a cloudy light orange color with no head. Superb aroma of fruits including green apples and grapes, its very sour and has a wine quality. Excellent flavor of grapes gummies, green apple, the sourness is mouth puckering, green apples and brett. Let me catch my breath here. bottle thanks to holdenn!.....pours a light hazy yellow orange with little to no head. some little white floaties meandering inside the glass....strong nose of white grapefruit juice with not much of anything else.  surely this cannot be it!....flavors of tart and acidic grapefruit. period.....i was looking for more more out of this sour ale.  it really lacked the complexity to make it shine.

Sampled at "An evening with Pantanap #2".  Pale dirty yellow color with slight white head.  Sour grapefruit juice aroma, dirty.  Flavor is Sour, grapefruit juice, acidic, mango, sour, tart.  Medium and sour.  The acidity is very unpleasant, I kind of wonder if this was better a bit fresher..

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2009 Sampled at "An evening with Pantanap #2". 750ml bottle.  Thanks to dickinsonbeer for this beer, a great guy!  Pours a murky yellow orange with a white ring of a fizzy head that fades quick.  Aroma is sweet and yeasty with grapefruit and spice notes.  Flavors are mostly grapefruit and acidity with tropical fruit and oak around the edges.  The acidity rapes my mouth, leaving it tart dry and slightly harsh.
